title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: There are things which are within our power, and there are things which are beyond our power.
sentences: there are things which are within our power and there are things which are beyond our power

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Within our power are opinion, aim, desire, aversion, and, in one word, whatever affairs are our own.
sentences: within our power are opinion aim desire aversion and in one word whatever affairs are our own

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Beyond our power are body, property, reputation, office, and, in one word, whatever are not properly our own affairs.
sentences: beyond our power are body property reputation office and in one word whatever are not properly our own affairs

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Now the things within our power are by nature free, unrestricted, unhindered; but those beyond our power are weak, dependent, restricted, alien.
sentences: now the things within our power are by nature free unrestricted unhindered but those beyond our power are weak dependent restricted alien

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Remember, then, that if you attribute freedom to things by nature dependent and take what belongs to others for your own, you will be hindered
sentences: remember then that if you attribute freedom to things by nature dependent and take what belongs to others for your own you will be hindered

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: , you will lament, you will be disturbed, you will find fault both with gods and men.
sentences: you will lament you will be disturbed you will find fault both with gods and men

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But if you take for your own only that which is your own and view what belongs to others just as it really is, then no one will ever compel you, no one will restrict you; you will find fault with no one, you will accuse no one, you will do nothing against your will; no one will hurt you, you will not have an enemy, nor will you suffer any harm.
sentences: but if you take for your own only that which is your own and view what belongs to others just as it really is then no one will ever compel you no one will restrict you you will find fault with no one you will accuse no one you will do nothing against your will no one will hurt you you will not have an enemy nor will you suffer any harm

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Aiming, therefore, at such great things, remember that you must not allow yourself any inclination, however slight, toward the attainment of the others; but that you must entirely quit some of them, and for the present postpone the rest.
sentences: aiming therefore at such great things remember that you must not allow yourself any inclination however slight toward the attainment of the others but that you must entirely quit some of them and for the present postpone the rest

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But if you would have these, and possess power and wealth likewise, you may miss the latter in seeking the former; and you will certainly fail of that by which alone happiness and freedom are procured.
sentences: but if you would have these and possess power and wealth likewise you may miss the latter in seeking the former and you will certainly fail of that by which alone happiness and freedom are procured

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Seek at once, therefore, to be able to say to every unpleasing semblance, 'You are but a semblance and by no means the real thing.'
sentences: seek at once therefore to be able to say to every unpleasing semblance you are but semblance and by no means the real thing

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And then examine it by those rules which you have; and first and chiefly by this: whether it concerns the things which are within our own power or those which are not; and if it concerns anything beyond our power, be prepared to say that it is nothing to you.
sentences: and then examine it by those rules which you have and first and chiefly by this whether it concerns the things which are within our own power or those which are not and if it concerns anything beyond our power be prepared to say that it is nothing to you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Remember that desire demands the attainment of that of which you are desirous; and aversion demands the avoidance of that to which you are averse; that he who fails of the object of his desires is disappointed; and he who incurs the object of his aversion is wretched.
sentences: remember that desire demands the attainment of that of which you are desirous and aversion demands the avoidance of that to which you are averse that he who fails of the object of his desires is disappointed and he who incurs the object of his aversion is wretched

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If, then, you shun only those undesirable things which you can control, you will never incur anything which you shun; but if you shun sickness, or death, or poverty, you will run the risk of wretchedness.
sentences: if then you shun only those undesirable things which you can control you will never incur anything which you shun but if you shun sickness or death or poverty you will run the risk of wretchedness

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Remove the habit of aversion, then, from all things that are not within our power, and apply it to things undesirable which are within our power.
sentences: remove the habit of aversion then from all things that are not within our power and apply it to things undesirable which are within our power

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But for the present, altogether restrain desire; for if you desire any of the things not within our own power, you must necessarily be disappointed; and you are not yet secure of those which are within our power, and so are legitimate objects of desire.
sentences: but for the present altogether restrain desire for if you desire any of the things not within our own power you must necessarily be disappointed and you are not yet secure of those which are within our power and so are legitimate objects of desire

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Where it is practically necessary for you to pursue or avoid anything, do even this with discretion and gentleness and moderation.
sentences: where it is practically necessary for you to pursue or avoid anything do even this with discretion and gentleness and moderation

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: With regard to whatever objects either delight the mind or contribute to use or are tenderly beloved, remind yourself of what nature they are, beginning with the merest trifles: if you have a favorite cup, that it is but a cup of which you are fond of for thus, if it is broken, you can bear it; if you embrace your child or your wife, that you embrace a mortal and thus, if either of them dies, you can bear it.
sentences: with regard to whatever objects either delight the mind or contribute to use or are tenderly beloved remind yourself of what nature they are beginning with the merest trifles if you have favorite cup that it is but cup of which you are fond of for thus if it is broken you can bear it if you embrace your child or your wife that you embrace mortal and thus if either of them dies you can bear it

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When you set about any action, remind yourself of what nature the action is.
sentences: when you set about any action remind yourself of what nature the action is

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If you are going to bathe, represent to yourself the incidents usual in the bath some persons pouring out, others pushing in, others scolding, others pilfering.
sentences: if you are going to bathe represent to yourself the incidents usual in the bath some persons pouring out others pushing in others scolding others pilfering

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And thus you will more safely go about this action if you say to yourself, 'I will now go to bathe and keep my own will in harmony with nature.'
sentences: and thus you will more safely go about this action if you say to yourself will now go to bathe and keep my own will in harmony with nature

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And so with regard to every other action.
sentences: and so with regard to every other action

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For thus, if any impediment arises in bathing, you will be able to say, 'It was not only to bathe that I desired, but to keep my will in harmony with nature; and I shall not keep it thus if I am out of humor at things that happen.'
sentences: for thus if any impediment arises in bathing you will be able to say it was not only to bathe that desired but to keep my will in harmony with nature and shall not keep it thus if am out of humor at things that happen

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Men are disturbed not by things, but by the views which they take of things.
sentences: men are disturbed not by things but by the views which they take of things

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Thus death is nothing terrible, else it would have appeared so to Socrates.
sentences: thus death is nothing terrible else it would have appeared so to socrates

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But the terror consists in our notion of death, that it is terrible.
sentences: but the terror consists in our notion of death that it is terrible

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When, therefore, we are hindered or disturbed, or grieved, let us never impute it to others, but to ourselves that is, to our own views.
sentences: when therefore we are hindered or disturbed or grieved let us never impute it to others but to ourselves that is to our own views

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: It is the action of an uninstructed person to reproach others for his own misfortunes; of one entering upon instruction, to reproach himself; and one perfectly instructed, to reproach neither others nor himself.
sentences: it is the action of an uninstructed person to reproach others for his own misfortunes of one entering upon instruction to reproach himself and one perfectly instructed to reproach neither others nor himself

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Be not elated at any excellence not your own.
sentences: be not elated at any excellence not your own

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If a horse should be elated, and say, 'I am handsome,' it might be endurable.
sentences: if horse should be elated and say am handsome it might be endurable

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But when you are elated and say, 'I have a handsome horse,' know that you are elated only on the merit of the horse.
sentences: but when you are elated and say have handsome horse know that you are elated only on the merit of the horse

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: What then is your own?
sentences: what then is your own

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The use of the phenomena of existence.
sentences: the use of the phenomena of existence

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: So that when you are in harmony with nature in this respect, you will be elated with some reason; for you will be elated at some good of your own.
sentences: so that when you are in harmony with nature in this respect you will be elated with some reason for you will be elated at some good of your own

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: As in a voyage, when the ship is at anchor, if you go on shore to get water, you may amuse yourself with picking up a shellfish or a truffle in your way, but your thoughts ought to be bent toward the ship, and perpetually attentive, lest the captain should call, and then you must leave all these things, that you may not have to be carried on board the vessel, bound like a sheep
sentences: as in voyage when the ship is at anchor if you go on shore to get water you may amuse yourself with picking up shellfish or truffle in your way but your thoughts ought to be bent toward the ship and perpetually attentive lest the captain should call and then you must leave all these things that you may not have to be carried on board the vessel bound like sheep

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: ; thus likewise in life, if, instead of a truffle or shellfish, such a thing as a wife or a child be granted you, there is no objection; but if the captain calls, run to the ship, leave all these things, and never look behind.
sentences: thus likewise in life if instead of truffle or shellfish such thing as wife or child be granted you there is no objection but if the captain calls run to the ship leave all these things and never look behind

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But if you are old, never go far from the ship, lest you should be missing when called for.
sentences: but if you are old never go far from the ship lest you should be missing when called for

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Demand not that events should happen as you wish; but wish them to happen as they do happen, and you will go on well.
sentences: demand not that events should happen as you wish but wish them to happen as they do happen and you will go on well

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Sickness is an impediment to the body, but not to the will unless itself pleases.
sentences: sickness is an impediment to the body but not to the will unless itself pleases

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Lameness is an impediment to the leg, but not to the will; and say this to yourself with regard to everything that happens.
sentences: lameness is an impediment to the leg but not to the will and say this to yourself with regard to everything that happens

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For you will find it to be an impediment to something else, but not truly to yourself.
sentences: for you will find it to be an impediment to something else but not truly to yourself

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Upon every accident, remember to turn toward yourself and inquire what faculty you have for its use.
sentences: upon every accident remember to turn toward yourself and inquire what faculty you have for its use

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If you encounter a handsome person, you will find continence the faculty needed; if pain, then fortitude; if reviling, then patience.
sentences: if you encounter handsome person you will find continence the faculty needed if pain then fortitude if reviling then patience

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And when thus habituated, the phenomena of existence will not overwhelm you.
sentences: and when thus habituated the phenomena of existence will not overwhelm you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Never say of anything, 'I have lost it,' but, 'I have restored it.'
sentences: never say of anything have lost it but have restored it

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Has your child died?
sentences: has your child died

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Has your estate been taken away?
sentences: has your estate been taken away

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: That likewise is restored. '
sentences: that likewise is restored

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But it was a bad man who took it.'
sentences: but it was bad man who took it

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: What is it to you by whose hands he who gave it has demanded it again?
sentences: what is it to you by whose hands he who gave it has demanded it again

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: While he permits you to possess it, hold it as something not your own, as do travelers at an inn.
sentences: while he permits you to possess it hold it as something not your own as do travelers at an inn

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you would improve, lay aside such reasonings as these: 'If I neglect my affairs, I shall not have a maintenance; if I do not punish my servant, he will be good for nothing.'
sentences: you would improve lay aside such reasonings as these if neglect my affairs shall not have maintenance if do not punish my servant he will be good for nothing

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For it were better to die of hunger, exempt from grief and fear, than to live in affluence with perturbation; and it is better that your servant should be bad than you unhappy.
sentences: for it were better to die of hunger exempt from grief and fear than to live in affluence with perturbation and it is better that your servant should be bad than you unhappy

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Begin therefore with little things.
sentences: begin therefore with little things

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Is a little oil spilled or a little wine stolen?
sentences: is little oil spilled or little wine stolen

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Say to yourself, 'This is the price paid for peace and tranquillity; and nothing is to be had for nothing.'
sentences: say to yourself this is the price paid for peace and tranquillity and nothing is to be had for nothing

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And when you call your servant, consider that it is possible he may not come at your call; or, if he does, that he may not do what you wish.
sentences: and when you call your servant consider that it is possible he may not come at your call or if he does that he may not do what you wish

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But it is not at all desirable for him, and very undesirable for you, that it should be in his power to cause you any disturbance.
sentences: but it is not at all desirable for him and very undesirable for you that it should be in his power to cause you any disturbance

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you would improve, be content to be thought foolish and dull with regard to externals.
sentences: you would improve be content to be thought foolish and dull with regard to externals

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Do not desire to be thought to know anything; and though you should appear to others to be somebody, distrust yourself.
sentences: do not desire to be thought to know anything and though you should appear to others to be somebody distrust yourself

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For be assured, it is not easy at once to keep your will in harmony with nature and to secure externals; but while you are absorbed in the one, you must of necessity neglect the other.
sentences: for be assured it is not easy at once to keep your will in harmony with nature and to secure externals but while you are absorbed in the one you must of necessity neglect the other

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you wish your children and your wife and your friends to live forever, you are foolish, for you wish things to be in your power which are not so, and what belongs to others to be your own.
sentences: you wish your children and your wife and your friends to live forever you are foolish for you wish things to be in your power which are not so and what belongs to others to be your own

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: So likewise, if you wish your servant to be without fault, you are foolish, for you wish vice not to be vice but something else.
sentences: so likewise if you wish your servant to be without fault you are foolish for you wish vice not to be vice but something else

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But if you wish not to be disappointed in your desires, that is in your own power.
sentences: but if you wish not to be disappointed in your desires that is in your own power

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Exercise, therefore, what is in your power.
sentences: exercise therefore what is in your power

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: A man's master is he who is able to confer or remove whatever that man seeks or shuns.
sentences: man master is he who is able to confer or remove whatever that man seeks or shuns

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Whoever then would be free, let him wish nothing, let him decline nothing, which depends on others; else he must necessarily be a slave.
sentences: whoever then would be free let him wish nothing let him decline nothing which depends on others else he must necessarily be slave

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Remember that you must behave as at a banquet.
sentences: remember that you must behave as at banquet

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Is anything brought round to you?
sentences: is anything brought round to you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Put out your hand and take a moderate share.
sentences: put out your hand and take moderate share

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Does it pass by you?
sentences: does it pass by you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Do not yearn in desire toward it, but wait till it reaches you.
sentences: do not yearn in desire toward it but wait till it reaches you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: So with regard to children, wife, office, riches; and you will some time or other be worthy to feast with the gods.
sentences: so with regard to children wife office riches and you will some time or other be worthy to feast with the gods

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And if you do not so much as take the things which are set before you, but are able even to forego them, then you will not only be worthy to feast with the gods, but to rule with them also.
sentences: and if you do not so much as take the things which are set before you but are able even to forego them then you will not only be worthy to feast with the gods but to rule with them also

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For, by thus doing, Diogenes and Heraclitus, and others like them, deservedly became divine, and were so recognized.
sentences: for by thus doing diogenes and heraclitus and others like them deservedly became divine and were so recognized

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When you see anyone weeping for grief, either that his son has gone abroad or that he has suffered in his affairs, take care not to be overcome by the apparent evil, but discriminate and be ready to say, 'What hurts this man is not this occurrence itself for another man might not be hurt by it
sentences: when you see anyone weeping for grief either that his son has gone abroad or that he has suffered in his affairs take care not to be overcome by the apparent evil but discriminate and be ready to say what hurts this man is not this occurrence itself for another man might not be hurt by it

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: but the view he chooses to take of it.'
sentences: but the view he chooses to take of it

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: As far as conversation goes, however, do not disdain to accommodate yourself to him and, if need be, to groan with him.
sentences: as far as conversation goes however do not disdain to accommodate yourself to him and if need be to groan with him

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Take heed, however, not to groan inwardly, too.
sentences: take heed however not to groan inwardly too

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Remember that you are an actor in a drama of such sort as the Author chooses if short, then in a short one; if long, then in a long one.
sentences: remember that you are an actor in drama of such sort as the author chooses if short then in short one if long then in long one

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If it be his pleasure that you should enact a poor man, or a cripple, or a ruler, or a private citizen, see that you act it well.
sentences: if it be his pleasure that you should enact poor man or cripple or ruler or private citizen see that you act it well

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For this is your business to act well the given part, but to choose it belongs to another.
sentences: for this is your business to act well the given part but to choose it belongs to another

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When a raven happens to croak unluckily, be not overcome by appearances, but discriminate and say, 'Nothing is portended to me either to my paltry body, or property, or reputation, or children, or wife.
sentences: when raven happens to croak unluckily be not overcome by appearances but discriminate and say nothing is portended to me either to my paltry body or property or reputation or children or wife

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But to me all portents are lucky if I will.
sentences: but to me all portents are lucky if will

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For whatsoever happens, it belongs to me to derive advantage therefrom.'
sentences: for whatsoever happens it belongs to me to derive advantage therefrom

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: You can be unconquerable if you enter into no combat in which it is not in your own power to conquer.
sentences: you can be unconquerable if you enter into no combat in which it is not in your own power to conquer

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When, therefore, you see anyone eminent in honors or power, or in high esteem on any other account, take heed not to be bewildered by appearances and to pronounce him happy; for if the essence of good consists in things within our own power, there will be no room for envy or emulation.
sentences: when therefore you see anyone eminent in honors or power or in high esteem on any other account take heed not to be bewildered by appearances and to pronounce him happy for if the essence of good consists in things within our own power there will be no room for envy or emulation

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But, for your part, do not desire to be a general, or a senator, or a consul, but to be free; and the only way to this is a disregard of things which lie not within our own power.
sentences: but for your part do not desire to be general or senator or consul but to be free and the only way to this is disregard of things which lie not within our own power

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Remember that it is not he who gives abuse or blows, who affronts, but the view we take of these things as insulting.
sentences: remember that it is not he who gives abuse or blows who affronts but the view we take of these things as insulting

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When, therefore, anyone provokes you, be assured that it is your own opinion which provokes you.
sentences: when therefore anyone provokes you be assured that it is your own opinion which provokes you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Try, therefore, in the first place, not to be bewildered by appearances.
sentences: try therefore in the first place not to be bewildered by appearances

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For if you once gain time and respite, you will more easily command yourself.
sentences: for if you once gain time and respite you will more easily command yourself

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Let death and exile, and all other things which appear terrible, be daily before your eyes, but death chiefly; and you will never entertain an abject thought, nor too eagerly covet anything.
sentences: let death and exile and all other things which appear terrible be daily before your eyes but death chiefly and you will never entertain an abject thought nor too eagerly covet anything

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you have an earnest desire toward philosophy, prepare yourself from the very first to have the multitude laugh and sneer, and say, 'He is returned to us a philosopher all at once'; and, 'Whence this supercilious look?'
sentences: you have an earnest desire toward philosophy prepare yourself from the very first to have the multitude laugh and sneer and say he is returned to us philosopher all at once and whence this supercilious look

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Now, for your part, do not have a supercilious look indeed, but keep steadily to those things which appear best to you, as one appointed by God to this particular station.
sentences: now for your part do not have supercilious look indeed but keep steadily to those things which appear best to you as one appointed by god to this particular station

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For remember that, if you are persistent, those very persons who at first ridiculed will afterwards admire you.
sentences: for remember that if you are persistent those very persons who at first ridiculed will afterwards admire you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But if you are conquered by them, you will incur a double ridicule.
sentences: but if you are conquered by them you will incur double ridicule

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you ever happen to turn your attention to externals, for the pleasure of anyone, be assured that you have ruined your scheme of life.
sentences: you ever happen to turn your attention to externals for the pleasure of anyone be assured that you have ruined your scheme of life

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Be content, then, in everything, with being a philosopher; and if you wish to seem so likewise to anyone, appear so to yourself, and it will suffice you.
sentences: be content then in everything with being philosopher and if you wish to seem so likewise to anyone appear so to yourself and it will suffice you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Let not such considerations as these distress you: 'I shall live in discredit and be nobody anywhere.'
sentences: let not such considerations as these distress you shall live in discredit and be nobody anywhere

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For if discredit be an evil, you can no more be involved in evil through another than in baseness.
sentences: for if discredit be an evil you can no more be involved in evil through another than in baseness

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Is it any business of yours, then, to get power or to be admitted to an entertainment?
sentences: is it any business of yours then to get power or to be admitted to an entertainment

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: How then, after all, is this discredit?
sentences: how then after all is this discredit

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And how it is true that you will be nobody anywhere when you ought to be somebody in those things only which are within your own power, in which you may be of the greatest consequence? '

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

title: Enchiridion

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: As when our neighbor's boy has broken a cup, or the like, we are ready at once to say, 'These are casualties that will happen'; be assured, then, that when your own cup is likewise broken, you ought to be affected just as when another's cup was broken.

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: You must conform to rules, submit to a diet, refrain from dainties; exercise your body, whether you choose it or not, at a stated hour, in heat and cold; you must drink no cold water, and sometimes no wine in a word, you must give yourself up to your trainer as to a physician.
sentences: you must conform to rules submit to diet refrain from dainties exercise your body whether you choose it or not at stated hour in heat and cold you must drink no cold water and sometimes no wine in word you must give yourself up to your trainer as to physician

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

sentences: then in the combat you may be thrown into ditch dislocate your arm turn your ankle swallow an abundance of dust receive stripes for negligence and after all lose the victory

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

sentences: when you have reckoned up all this if your inclination still holds set about the combat

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Otherwise, take notice, you will behave like children who sometimes play wrestlers, sometimes gladiators, sometimes blow a trumpet, and sometimes act a tragedy, when they happen to have seen and admired these shows.
sentences: otherwise take notice you will behave like children who sometimes play wrestlers sometimes gladiators sometimes blow trumpet and sometimes act tragedy when they happen to have seen and admired these shows

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

sentences: like an ape you mimic all you see and one thing after another is sure to please you but is out of favor as soon as it becomes familiar

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Consider first, man, what the matter is, and what your own nature is able to bear.

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

sentences: you must watch you must labor you must get the better of certain appetites must quit your acquaintances be despised by your servant be laughed at by those you meet come off worse than others in everything in offices in honors before tribunals

author: Epictetus

sentences: when you have fully considered all these things approach if you please that is if by parting with them you have mind to purchase serenity freedom and tranquillity

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Duties are universally measured by relations.

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus

sentences: well preserve your own just relation toward him

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Consider not what he does, but what you are to do to keep your own will in a state conformable to nature, for another cannot hurt you unless you please.
sentences: consider not what he does but what you are to do to keep your own will in state conformable to nature for another cannot hurt you unless you please

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: You will then be hurt when you consent to be hurt.

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: In this manner, therefore, if you accustom yourself to contemplate the relations of neighbor, citizen, commander, you can deduce from each the corresponding duties.
sentences: in this manner therefore if you accustom yourself to contemplate the relations of neighbor citizen commander you can deduce from each the corresponding duties

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Be assured that the essence of piety toward the gods lies in this to form right opinions concerning them, as existing and as governing the universe justly and well.
sentences: be assured that the essence of piety toward the gods lies in this to form right opinions concerning them as existing and as governing the universe justly and well

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And fix yourself in this resolution, to obey them, and yield to them, and willingly follow them amidst all events, as being ruled by the most perfect wisdom.
sentences: and fix yourself in this resolution to obey them and yield to them and willingly follow them amidst all events as being ruled by the most perfect wisdom

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For thus you will never find fault with the gods, nor accuse them of neglecting you.
sentences: for thus you will never find fault with the gods nor accuse them of neglecting you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And it is not possible for this to be affected in any other way than by withdrawing yourself from things which are not within our own power, and by making good or evil to consist only in those which are.
sentences: and it is not possible for this to be affected in any other way than by withdrawing yourself from things which are not within our own power and by making good or evil to consist only in those which are

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For if you suppose any other things to be either good or evil, it is inevitable that, when you are disappointed of what you wish or incur what you would avoid, you should reproach and blame their authors.
sentences: for if you suppose any other things to be either good or evil it is inevitable that when you are disappointed of what you wish or incur what you would avoid you should reproach and blame their authors

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

author: Epictetus
