title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: It is impracticable, then, that one who supposes himself to be hurt should rejoice in the person who, as he thinks, hurts him, just as it is impossible to rejoice in the hurt itself.
sentences: it is impracticable then that one who supposes himself to be hurt should rejoice in the person who as he thinks hurts him just as it is impossible to rejoice in the hurt itself

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Hence, also, a father is reviled by his son when he does not impart the things which seem to be good; and this made Polynices and Eteocles mutually enemies that empire seemed good to both.
sentences: hence also father is reviled by his son when he does not impart the things which seem to be good and this made polynices and eteocles mutually enemies that empire seemed good to both

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: On this account the husbandman reviles the gods; and so do the sailor, the merchant, or those who have lost wife or child.
sentences: on this account the husbandman reviles the gods and so do the sailor the merchant or those who have lost wife or child

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For where our interest is, there, too, is piety directed.
sentences: for where our interest is there too is piety directed

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: So that whoever is careful to regulate his desires and aversions as he ought is thus made careful of piety likewise.
sentences: so that whoever is careful to regulate his desires and aversions as he ought is thus made careful of piety likewise

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But it also becomes incumbent on everyone to offer libations and sacrifices and first fruits, according to the customs of his country, purely, and not heedlessly nor negligently; not avariciously, nor yet extravagantly.
sentences: but it also becomes incumbent on everyone to offer libations and sacrifices and first fruits according to the customs of his country purely and not heedlessly nor negligently not avariciously nor yet extravagantly

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When you have recourse to divination, remember that you know not what the event will be, and you come to learn it of the diviner; but of what nature it is you knew before coming; at least, if you are of philosophic mind.
sentences: when you have recourse to divination remember that you know not what the event will be and you come to learn it of the diviner but of what nature it is you knew before coming at least if you are of philosophic mind

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For if it is among the things not within our own power, it can by no means be either good or evil.
sentences: for if it is among the things not within our own power it can by no means be either good or evil

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Do not, therefore, bring with you to the diviner either desire or aversion else
sentences: do not therefore bring with you to the diviner either desire or aversion else

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you will approach him trembling but first clearly understand that every event is indifferent and nothing to you of whatever sort it may be; for it will be in your power to make a right use of it, and this no one can hinder.
sentences: you will approach him trembling but first clearly understand that every event is indifferent and nothing to you of whatever sort it may be for it will be in your power to make right use of it and this no one can hinder

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Then come with confidence to the gods as your counselors; and afterwards, when any counsel is given you, remember what counselors you have assumed, and whose advice you will neglect if you disobey.
sentences: then come with confidence to the gods as your counselors and afterwards when any counsel is given you remember what counselors you have assumed and whose advice you will neglect if you disobey

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Come to divination as Socrates prescribed, in cases of which the whole consideration relates to the event, and in which no opportunities are afforded by reason or any other art to discover the matter in view.
sentences: come to divination as socrates prescribed in cases of which the whole consideration relates to the event and in which no opportunities are afforded by reason or any other art to discover the matter in view

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When, therefore, it is our duty to share the danger of a friend or of our country, we ought not to consult the oracle as to whether we shall share it with them or not.
sentences: when therefore it is our duty to share the danger of friend or of our country we ought not to consult the oracle as to whether we shall share it with them or not

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For though the diviner should forewarn you that the auspices are unfavorable, this means no more than that either death or mutilation or exile is portended.
sentences: for though the diviner should forewarn you that the auspices are unfavorable this means no more than that either death or mutilation or exile is portended

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But we have reason within us; and it directs us, even with these hazards, to stand by our friend and our country.
sentences: but we have reason within us and it directs us even with these hazards to stand by our friend and our country

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Attend, therefore, to the greater diviner, the Pythian God, who once cast out of the temple him who neglected to save his friend.
sentences: attend therefore to the greater diviner the pythian god who once cast out of the temple him who neglected to save his friend

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Begin by prescribing to yourself some character and demeanor, such as you may preserve both alone and in company.
sentences: begin by prescribing to yourself some character and demeanor such as you may preserve both alone and in company

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Be mostly silent, or speak merely what is needful, and in few words.
sentences: be mostly silent or speak merely what is needful and in few words

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: We may, however, enter sparingly into discourse sometimes, when occasion calls for it; but let it not run on any of the common subjects, as gladiators, or horse races, or athletic champions, or food, or drink the vulgar topics of conversation and especially not on men, so as either to blame, or praise, or make comparisons.
sentences: we may however enter sparingly into discourse sometimes when occasion calls for it but let it not run on any of the common subjects as gladiators or horse races or athletic champions or food or drink the vulgar topics of conversation and especially not on men so as either to blame or praise or make comparisons

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If you are able, then, by your own conversation, bring over that of your company to proper subjects; but if you happen to find yourself among strangers, be silent.
sentences: if you are able then by your own conversation bring over that of your company to proper subjects but if you happen to find yourself among strangers be silent

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Let not your laughter be loud, frequent, or abundant.
sentences: let not your laughter be loud frequent or abundant

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Avoid taking oaths, if possible, altogether; at any rate, so far as you are able.
sentences: avoid taking oaths if possible altogether at any rate so far as you are able

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Avoid public and vulgar entertainments; but if ever an occasion calls you to them, keep your attention upon the stretch, that you may not imperceptibly slide into vulgarity.
sentences: avoid public and vulgar entertainments but if ever an occasion calls you to them keep your attention upon the stretch that you may not imperceptibly slide into vulgarity

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For be assured that if a person be ever so pure himself, yet, if his companion be corrupted, he who converses with him will be corrupted likewise.
sentences: for be assured that if person be ever so pure himself yet if his companion be corrupted he who converses with him will be corrupted likewise

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Provide things relating to the body no further than absolute need requires, as meat, drink, clothing, house, retinue.
sentences: provide things relating to the body no further than absolute need requires as meat drink clothing house retinue

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But cut off everything that looks toward show and luxury.
sentences: but cut off everything that looks toward show and luxury

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Before marriage guard yourself with all your ability from unlawful intercourse with women; yet be not uncharitable or severe to those who are led into this, nor boast frequently that you yourself do otherwise.
sentences: before marriage guard yourself with all your ability from unlawful intercourse with women yet be not uncharitable or severe to those who are led into this nor boast frequently that you yourself do otherwise

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If anyone tells you that a certain person speaks ill of you, do not make excuses about what is said of you, but answer: 'He was ignorant of my other faults, else he would not have mentioned these alone.'
sentences: if anyone tells you that certain person speaks ill of you do not make excuses about what is said of you but answer he was ignorant of my other faults else he would not have mentioned these alone

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: It is not necessary for you to appear often at public spectacles; but if ever there is a proper occasion for you to be there, do not appear more solicitous for any other than for yourself that is, wish things to be only just as they are, and only the best man to win; for thus nothing will go against you.
sentences: it is not necessary for you to appear often at public spectacles but if ever there is proper occasion for you to be there do not appear more solicitous for any other than for yourself that is wish things to be only just as they are and only the best man to win for thus nothing will go against you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But abstain entirely from acclamations and derision and violent emotions.
sentences: but abstain entirely from acclamations and derision and violent emotions

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And when you come away, do not discourse a great deal on what has passed and what contributes nothing to your own amendment.
sentences: and when you come away do not discourse great deal on what has passed and what contributes nothing to your own amendment

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For it would appear by such discourse that you were dazzled by the show.
sentences: for it would appear by such discourse that you were dazzled by the show

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Be not prompt or ready to attend private recitations; but if you do attend, preserve your gravity and dignity, and yet avoid making yourself disagreeable.
sentences: be not prompt or ready to attend private recitations but if you do attend preserve your gravity and dignity and yet avoid making yourself disagreeable

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When you are going to confer with anyone, and especially with one who seems your superior, represent to yourself how Socrates or Zeno would behave in such a case, and you will not be at a loss to meet properly whatever may occur.
sentences: when you are going to confer with anyone and especially with one who seems your superior represent to yourself how socrates or zeno would behave in such case and you will not be at loss to meet properly whatever may occur

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When you are going before anyone in power, fancy to yourself that you may not find him at home, that you may be shut out, that the doors may not be opened to you, that he may not notice you.
sentences: when you are going before anyone in power fancy to yourself that you may not find him at home that you may be shut out that the doors may not be opened to you that he may not notice you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If, with all this, it be your duty to go, bear what happens and never say to yourself, 'It was not worth so much'; for this is vulgar, and like a man bewildered by externals.
sentences: if with all this it be your duty to go bear what happens and never say to yourself it was not worth so much for this is vulgar and like man bewildered by externals

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: In company, avoid a frequent and excessive mention of your own actions and dangers.
sentences: in company avoid frequent and excessive mention of your own actions and dangers

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For however agreeable it may be to yourself to allude to the risks you have run, it is not equally agreeable to others to hear your adventures.
sentences: for however agreeable it may be to yourself to allude to the risks you have run it is not equally agreeable to others to hear your adventures

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Avoid likewise an endeavor to excite laughter, for this may readily slide you into vulgarity, and, besides, may be apt to lower you in the esteem of your acquaintance.
sentences: avoid likewise an endeavor to excite laughter for this may readily slide you into vulgarity and besides may be apt to lower you in the esteem of your acquaintance

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Approaches to indecent discourse are likewise dangerous.
sentences: approaches to indecent discourse are likewise dangerous

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Therefore, when anything of this sort happens, use the first fit opportunity to rebuke him who makes advances that way, or, at least, by silence and blushing and a serious look show yourself to be displeased by such talk.
sentences: therefore when anything of this sort happens use the first fit opportunity to rebuke him who makes advances that way or at least by silence and blushing and serious look show yourself to be displeased by such talk

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you are dazzled by the semblance of any promised pleasure, guard yourself against being bewildered by it; but let the affair wait your leisure, and procure yourself some delay.
sentences: you are dazzled by the semblance of any promised pleasure guard yourself against being bewildered by it but let the affair wait your leisure and procure yourself some delay

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Then bring to your mind both points of time that in which you shall enjoy the pleasure, and that in which you will repent and reproach yourself, after you have enjoyed it and set before you, in opposition to these, how you will rejoice and applaud yourself if you abstain.
sentences: then bring to your mind both points of time that in which you shall enjoy the pleasure and that in which you will repent and reproach yourself after you have enjoyed it and set before you in opposition to these how you will rejoice and applaud yourself if you abstain

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And even though it should appear to you a seasonable gratification, take heed that its enticements and allurements and seductions may not subdue you, but set in opposition to this
sentences: and even though it should appear to you seasonable gratification take heed that its enticements and allurements and seductions may not subdue you but set in opposition to this

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: how much better it is to be conscious of having gained so great a victory.
sentences: how much better it is to be conscious of having gained so great victory

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When you do anything from a clear judgment that it ought to be done, never shrink from being seen to do it, even though the world should misunderstand it; for if you are not acting rightly, shun the action itself; if you are, why fear those who wrongly censure you?
sentences: when you do anything from clear judgment that it ought to be done never shrink from being seen to do it even though the world should misunderstand it for if you are not acting rightly shun the action itself if you are why fear those who wrongly censure you

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: As the proposition, 'either it is day or it is night,' has much force in a disjunctive argument, but none at all in a conjunctive one, so, at a feast, to choose the largest share is very suitable to the bodily appetite, but utterly inconsistent with the social spirit of the entertainment.
sentences: as the proposition either it is day or it is night has much force in disjunctive argument but none at all in conjunctive one so at feast to choose the largest share is very suitable to the bodily appetite but utterly inconsistent with the social spirit of the entertainment

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Remember, then, when you eat with another, not only the value to the body of those things which are set before you, but also the value of proper courtesy toward your host.
sentences: remember then when you eat with another not only the value to the body of those things which are set before you but also the value of proper courtesy toward your host

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: you have assumed any character beyond your strength, you have both demeaned yourself ill in that and quitted one which you might have supported.
sentences: you have assumed any character beyond your strength you have both demeaned yourself ill in that and quitted one which you might have supported

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: As in walking you take care not to tread upon a nail, or turn your foot, so likewise take care not to hurt the ruling faculty of your mind.
sentences: as in walking you take care not to tread upon nail or turn your foot so likewise take care not to hurt the ruling faculty of your mind

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And if we were to guard against this in every action, we should enter upon action more safely.
sentences: and if we were to guard against this in every action we should enter upon action more safely

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The body is to everyone the proper measure of its possessions, as the foot is of the shoe.
sentences: the body is to everyone the proper measure of its possessions as the foot is of the shoe

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If, therefore, you stop at this, you will keep the measure; but if you move beyond it, you must necessarily be carried forward, as down a precipice;
sentences: if therefore you stop at this you will keep the measure but if you move beyond it you must necessarily be carried forward as down precipice

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: as in the case of a shoe, if you go beyond its fitness to the foot, it comes first to be gilded, then purple, and then studded with jewels.
sentences: as in the case of shoe if you go beyond its fitness to the foot it comes first to be gilded then purple and then studded with jewels

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For to that which once exceeds the fit measure there is no bound.
sentences: for to that which once exceeds the fit measure there is no bound

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Women from fourteen years old are flattered by men with the title of mistresses.
sentences: women from fourteen years old are flattered by men with the title of mistresses

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Therefore, perceiving that they are regarded only as qualified to give men pleasure, they begin to adorn themselves, and in that to place all their hopes.
sentences: therefore perceiving that they are regarded only as qualified to give men pleasure they begin to adorn themselves and in that to place all their hopes

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: It is worth while, therefore, to try that they may perceive themselves honored only so far as they appear beautiful in their demeanor and modestly virtuous.
sentences: it is worth while therefore to try that they may perceive themselves honored only so far as they appear beautiful in their demeanor and modestly virtuous

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: is a mark of want of intellect to spend much time in things relating to the body, as to be immoderate in exercises, in eating and drinking, and in the discharge of other animal functions.
sentences: is mark of want of intellect to spend much time in things relating to the body as to be immoderate in exercises in eating and drinking and in the discharge of other animal functions

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: These things should be done incidentally and our main strength be applied to our reason.
sentences: these things should be done incidentally and our main strength be applied to our reason

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When any person does ill by you, or speaks ill of you, remember that he acts or speaks from an impression that it is right for him to do so.
sentences: when any person does ill by you or speaks ill of you remember that he acts or speaks from an impression that it is right for him to do so

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Now it is not possible that he should follow what appears right to you, but only what appears so to himself.
sentences: now it is not possible that he should follow what appears right to you but only what appears so to himself

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Therefore, if he judges from false appearances, he is the person hurt, since he, too, is the person deceived.
sentences: therefore if he judges from false appearances he is the person hurt since he too is the person deceived

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For if anyone takes a true proposition to be false, the proposition is not hurt, but only the man is deceived.
sentences: for if anyone takes true proposition to be false the proposition is not hurt but only the man is deceived

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Setting out, then, from these principles, you will meekly bear with a person who reviles you, for you will say upon every occasion, 'It seemed so to him.'
sentences: setting out then from these principles you will meekly bear with person who reviles you for you will say upon every occasion it seemed so to him

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Everything has two handles: one by which it may be borne, another by which it cannot.
sentences: everything has two handles one by which it may be borne another by which it cannot

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If your brother acts unjustly, do not lay hold on the affair by the handle of his injustice, for by that it cannot be borne, but rather by the opposite that he is your brother, that he was brought up with you; and thus you will lay hold on it as it is to be borne.
sentences: if your brother acts unjustly do not lay hold on the affair by the handle of his injustice for by that it cannot be borne but rather by the opposite that he is your brother that he was brought up with you and thus you will lay hold on it as it is to be borne

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: These reasonings have no logical connection: 'I am richer than you, therefore I am your superior.'
sentences: these reasonings have no logical connection am richer than you therefore am your superior

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: I am more eloquent than you, therefore I am your superior.'
sentences: am more eloquent than you therefore am your superior

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The true logical connection is rather this: 'I am richer than you, therefore my possessions must exceed yours.'
sentences: the true logical connection is rather this am richer than you therefore my possessions must exceed yours

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: 'I am more eloquent than you, therefore my style must surpass yours.'
sentences: am more eloquent than you therefore my style must surpass yours

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But you, after all, consist neither in property nor in style.
sentences: but you after all consist neither in property nor in style

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Does anyone bathe hastily?
sentences: does anyone bathe hastily

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Do not say that he does it ill, but hastily.
sentences: do not say that he does it ill but hastily

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Does anyone drink much wine?
sentences: does anyone drink much wine

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Do not say that he does ill, but that he drinks a great deal.
sentences: do not say that he does ill but that he drinks great deal

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For unless you perfectly understand his motives, how should you know if he acts ill?
sentences: for unless you perfectly understand his motives how should you know if he acts ill

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Thus you will not risk yielding to any appearances but such as you fully comprehend.
sentences: thus you will not risk yielding to any appearances but such as you fully comprehend

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Never proclaim yourself a philosopher, nor make much talk among the ignorant about your principles, but show them by actions.
sentences: never proclaim yourself philosopher nor make much talk among the ignorant about your principles but show them by actions

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Thus, at an entertainment, do not discourse how people ought to eat, but eat as you ought.
sentences: thus at an entertainment do not discourse how people ought to eat but eat as you ought

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For remember that thus Socrates also universally avoided all ostentation.
sentences: for remember that thus socrates also universally avoided all ostentation

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And when persons came to him and desired to be introduced by him to philosophers, he took them and introduced them; so well did he bear being overlooked.
sentences: and when persons came to him and desired to be introduced by him to philosophers he took them and introduced them so well did he bear being overlooked

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: So if ever there should be among the ignorant any discussion of principles, be for the most part silent.
sentences: so if ever there should be among the ignorant any discussion of principles be for the most part silent

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For there is great danger in hastily throwing out what is undigested.
sentences: for there is great danger in hastily throwing out what is undigested

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And if anyone tells you that you know nothing, and you are not nettled at it, then you may be sure that you have really entered on your work.
sentences: and if anyone tells you that you know nothing and you are not nettled at it then you may be sure that you have really entered on your work

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For sheep do not hastily throw up the grass to show the shepherds how much they have eaten, but, inwardly digesting their food, they produce it outwardly in wool and milk.
sentences: for sheep do not hastily throw up the grass to show the shepherds how much they have eaten but inwardly digesting their food they produce it outwardly in wool and milk

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Thus, therefore, do you not make an exhibition before the ignorant of your principles, but of the actions to which their digestion gives rise.
sentences: thus therefore do you not make an exhibition before the ignorant of your principles but of the actions to which their digestion gives rise

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When you have learned to nourish your body frugally, do not pique yourself upon it; nor, if you drink water, be saying upon every occasion, 'I drink water.'
sentences: when you have learned to nourish your body frugally do not pique yourself upon it nor if you drink water be saying upon every occasion drink water

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But first consider how much more frugal are the poor than we, and how much more patient of hardship.
sentences: but first consider how much more frugal are the poor than we and how much more patient of hardship

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If at any time you would inure yourself by exercise to labor and privation, for your own sake and not for the public, do not attempt great feats; but when you are violently thirsty, just rinse your mouth with water, and tell nobody.
sentences: if at any time you would inure yourself by exercise to labor and privation for your own sake and not for the public do not attempt great feats but when you are violently thirsty just rinse your mouth with water and tell nobody

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The condition and characteristic of a vulgar person is that he never looks for either help or harm from himself, but only from externals.
sentences: the condition and characteristic of vulgar person is that he never looks for either help or harm from himself but only from externals

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The condition and characteristic of a philosopher is that he looks to himself for all help or harm.
sentences: the condition and characteristic of philosopher is that he looks to himself for all help or harm

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The marks of a proficient are that he censures no one, praises no one, blames no one, accuses no one; says nothing concerning himself as being anybody or knowing anything.
sentences: the marks of proficient are that he censures no one praises no one blames no one accuses no one says nothing concerning himself as being anybody or knowing anything

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When he is in any instance hindered or restrained, he accuses himself; and if he is praised, he smiles to himself at the person who praises him; and if he is censured, he makes no defense.
sentences: when he is in any instance hindered or restrained he accuses himself and if he is praised he smiles to himself at the person who praises him and if he is censured he makes no defense

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But he goes about with the caution of a convalescent, careful of interference with anything that is doing well but not yet quite secure.
sentences: but he goes about with the caution of convalescent careful of interference with anything that is doing well but not yet quite secure

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: He restrains desire; he transfers his aversion to those things only which thwart the proper use of our own will; he employs his energies moderately in all directions; if he appears stupid or ignorant, he does not care; and, in a word, he keeps watch over himself as over an enemy and one in ambush.
sentences: he restrains desire he transfers his aversion to those things only which thwart the proper use of our own will he employs his energies moderately in all directions if he appears stupid or ignorant he does not care and in word he keeps watch over himself as over an enemy and one in ambush

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When anyone shows himself vain on being able to understand and interpret the works of Chrysippus, say to yourself: 'Unless Chrysippus had written obscurely, this person would have had nothing to be vain of.
sentences: when anyone shows himself vain on being able to understand and interpret the works of chrysippus say to yourself unless chrysippus had written obscurely this person would have had nothing to be vain of

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But what do I desire?
sentences: but what do desire

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: To understand nature, and follow her.
sentences: to understand nature and follow her

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: I ask, then, who interprets her; and hearing that Chrysippus does, I have recourse to him.
sentences: ask then who interprets her and hearing that chrysippus does have recourse to him

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: I do not understand his writings.
sentences: do not understand his writings

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: I seek, therefore, one to interpret them .'
sentences: seek therefore one to interpret them

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: So far there is nothing to value myself upon.
sentences: so far there is nothing to value myself upon

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And when I find an interpreter, what remains is to make use of his instructions.
sentences: and when find an interpreter what remains is to make use of his instructions

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: This alone is the valuable thing.
sentences: this alone is the valuable thing

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But if I admire merely the interpretation, what do I become more than a grammarian, instead of a philosopher, except, indeed, that instead of Homer I interpret Chrysippus?
sentences: but if admire merely the interpretation what do become more than grammarian instead of philosopher except indeed that instead of homer interpret chrysippus

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: When anyone, therefore, desires me to read Chrysippus to him, I rather blush when I cannot exhibit actions that are harmonious and consonant with his discourse.
sentences: when anyone therefore desires me to read chrysippus to him rather blush when cannot exhibit actions that are harmonious and consonant with his discourse

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Whatever rules you have adopted, abide by them as laws, and as if you would be impious to transgress them; and do not regard what anyone says of you, for this, after all, is no concern of yours.
sentences: whatever rules you have adopted abide by them as laws and as if you would be impious to transgress them and do not regard what anyone says of you for this after all is no concern of yours

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: How long, then, will you delay to demand of yourself the noblest improvements, and in no instance to transgress the judgments of reason?
sentences: how long then will you delay to demand of yourself the noblest improvements and in no instance to transgress the judgments of reason

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: You have received the philosophic principles with which you ought to be conversant; and you have been conversant with them.
sentences: you have received the philosophic principles with which you ought to be conversant and you have been conversant with them

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For what other master, then, do you wait as an excuse for this delay in self reformation?
sentences: for what other master then do you wait as an excuse for this delay in self reformation

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: You are no longer a boy but a grown man.
sentences: you are no longer boy but grown man

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: If, therefore, you will be negligent and slothful, and always add procrastination to procrastination, purpose to purpose, and fix day after day in which you will attend to yourself, you will insensibly continue to accomplish nothing and, living and dying, remain of vulgar mind.
sentences: if therefore you will be negligent and slothful and always add procrastination to procrastination purpose to purpose and fix day after day in which you will attend to yourself you will insensibly continue to accomplish nothing and living and dying remain of vulgar mind

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: This instant, then, think yourself worthy of living as a man grown up and a proficient.
sentences: this instant then think yourself worthy of living as man grown up and proficient

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Let whatever appears to be the best be to you an inviolable law.
sentences: let whatever appears to be the best be to you an inviolable law

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And if any instance of pain or pleasure, glory or disgrace, be set before you, remember that now is the combat, now the Olympiad comes on, nor can it be put off; and that by one failure and defeat honor may be lost or won.
sentences: and if any instance of pain or pleasure glory or disgrace be set before you remember that now is the combat now the olympiad comes on nor can it be put off and that by one failure and defeat honor may be lost or won

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Thus Socrates became perfect, improving himself by everything, following reason alone.
sentences: thus socrates became perfect improving himself by everything following reason alone

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: And though you are not yet a Socrates, you ought, however, to live as one seeking to be a Socrates.
sentences: and though you are not yet socrates you ought however to live as one seeking to be socrates

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The first and most necessary topic in philosophy is the practical application of principles, as, We ought not to lie the second
sentences: the first and most necessary topic in philosophy is the practical application of principles as we ought not to lie the second

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: is that of demonstrations as,
sentences: is that of demonstrations as

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Why it is that we ought not to lie the third, that which gives strength and logical connection to the other two, as, Why this is a demonstration.
sentences: why it is that we ought not to lie the third that which gives strength and logical connection to the other two as why this is demonstration

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For what is demonstration?
sentences: for what is demonstration

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: What is a consequence?
sentences: what is consequence

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: What a contradiction?
sentences: what contradiction

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: The third point is then necessary on account of the second; and the second on account of the first.
sentences: the third point is then necessary on account of the second and the second on account of the first

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But the most necessary, and that whereon we ought to rest, is the first.
sentences: but the most necessary and that whereon we ought to rest is the first

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: But we do just the contrary.
sentences: but we do just the contrary

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: For we spend all our time on the third point and employ all our diligence about that, and entirely neglect the first.
sentences: for we spend all our time on the third point and employ all our diligence about that and entirely neglect the first

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Therefore, at the same time that we lie, we are very ready to show how it is demonstrated that lying is wrong.
sentences: therefore at the same time that we lie we are very ready to show how it is demonstrated that lying is wrong

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Upon all occasions we ought to have these maxims ready at hand: Conduct me, Zeus, and thou, Destiny, Wherever your decrees have fixed my lot.
sentences: upon all occasions we ought to have these maxims ready at hand conduct me zeus and thou destiny wherever your decrees have fixed my lot

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: I follow cheerfully; and, did I not, Wicked and wretched, I must follow still.
sentences: follow cheerfully and did not wicked and wretched must follow still

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Who'er yields properly to Fate is deemed Wise among men, and knows the laws of Heaven.
sentences: who er yields properly to fate is deemed wise among men and knows the laws of heaven

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: O Crito, if it thus pleases the gods, thus let it be.' '
sentences: crito if it thus pleases the gods thus let it be

title: Enchiridion
author: Epictetus
sentence_str: Anytus and Melitus may kill me indeed; but hurt me they cannot.'
sentences: anytus and melitus may kill me indeed but hurt me they cannot

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whensoever thou wilt rejoice thyself, think and meditate upon those good parts and especial gifts, which thou hast observed in any of them that live with thee: as industry in one, in another modesty, in another bountifulness, in another some other thing.
sentences: whensoever thou wilt rejoice thyself think and meditate upon those good parts and especial gifts which thou hast observed in any of them that live with thee as industry in one in another modesty in another bountifulness in another some other thing

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For nothing can so much rejoice thee, as the resemblances and parallels of several virtues, eminent in the dispositions of them that live with thee, especially when all at once, as it were, they represent themselves unto thee.
sentences: for nothing can so much rejoice thee as the resemblances and parallels of several virtues eminent in the dispositions of them that live with thee especially when all at once as it were they represent themselves unto thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: See therefore, that thou have them always in a readiness.
sentences: see therefore that thou have them always in readiness

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of my grandfather Verus I have learned to be gentle and meek, and to refrain from all anger and passion.
sentences: of my grandfather verus have learned to be gentle and meek and to refrain from all anger and passion

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: From the fame and memory of him that begot me
sentences: from the fame and memory of him that begot me

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: I have learned both shamefastness and manlike behaviour.
sentences: have learned both shamefastness and manlike behaviour

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of my mother I have learned to be religious, and bountiful; and to forbear, not only to do, but to intend any evil; to content myself with a spare diet, and to fly all such excess as is incidental to great wealth.
sentences: of my mother have learned to be religious and bountiful and to forbear not only to do but to intend any evil to content myself with spare diet and to fly all such excess as is incidental to great wealth

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of my great grandfather, both to frequent public schools and auditories, and to get me good and able teachers at home; and that I ought not to think much, if upon such occasions, I were at excessive charges.
sentences: of my great grandfather both to frequent public schools and auditories and to get me good and able teachers at home and that ought not to think much if upon such occasions were at excessive charges

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of him that brought me up, not to be fondly addicted to either of the two great factions of the coursers in the circus, called Prasini, and Veneti: nor in the amphitheatre partially to favour any of the gladiators, or fencers, as either the Parmularii, or the Secutores.
sentences: of him that brought me up not to be fondly addicted to either of the two great factions of the coursers in the circus called prasini and veneti nor in the amphitheatre partially to favour any of the gladiators or fencers as either the parmularii or the secutores

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Moreover, to endure labour; nor to need many things; when I have anything to do, to do it myself rather than by others; not to meddle with many businesses; and not easily to admit of any slander.
sentences: moreover to endure labour nor to need many things when have anything to do to do it myself rather than by others not to meddle with many businesses and not easily to admit of any slander

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of Diognetus, not to busy myself about vain things, and not easily to believe those things, which are commonly spoken, by such as take upon them to work wonders, and by sorcerers, or prestidigitators, and impostors; concerning the power of charms, and their driving out of demons, or evil spirits; and the like.
sentences: of diognetus not to busy myself about vain things and not easily to believe those things which are commonly spoken by such as take upon them to work wonders and by sorcerers or prestidigitators and impostors concerning the power of charms and their driving out of demons or evil spirits and the like

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Not to keep quails for the game; nor to be mad after such things.
sentences: not to keep quails for the game nor to be mad after such things

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Not to be offended with other men's liberty of speech, and to apply myself unto philosophy.
sentences: not to be offended with other men liberty of speech and to apply myself unto philosophy

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Him also I must thank, that ever I heard first Bacchius, then Tandasis and Marcianus, and that I did write dialogues in my youth; and that I took liking to the philosophers' little couch and skins, and such other things, which by the Grecian discipline are proper to those who profess philosophy.
sentences: him also must thank that ever heard first bacchius then tandasis and marcianus and that did write dialogues in my youth and that took liking to the philosophers little couch and skins and such other things which by the grecian discipline are proper to those who profess philosophy

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: To Rusticus I am beholding, that I first entered into the conceit that my life wanted some redress and cure.
sentences: to rusticus am beholding that first entered into the conceit that my life wanted some redress and cure

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And then, that I did not fall into the ambition of ordinary sophists, either to write tracts concerning the common theorems, or to exhort men unto virtue and the study of philosophy by public orations; as also that I never by way of ostentation did affect to show myself an active able man, for any kind of bodily exercises.
sentences: and then that did not fall into the ambition of ordinary sophists either to write tracts concerning the common theorems or to exhort men unto virtue and the study of philosophy by public orations as also that never by way of ostentation did affect to show myself an active able man for any kind of bodily exercises

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And that I gave over the study of rhetoric and poetry, and of elegant neat language.
sentences: and that gave over the study of rhetoric and poetry and of elegant neat language

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: That I did not use to walk about the house in my long robe, nor to do any such things.
sentences: that did not use to walk about the house in my long robe nor to do any such things

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Moreover I learned of him to write letters without any affectation, or curiosity; such as that was, which by him was written to my mother from Sinuessa: and to be easy and ready to be reconciled, and well pleased again with them that had offended me, as soon as any of them would be content to seek unto me again.
sentences: moreover learned of him to write letters without any affectation or curiosity such as that was which by him was written to my mother from sinuessa and to be easy and ready to be reconciled and well pleased again with them that had offended me as soon as any of them would be content to seek unto me again

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: To read with diligence; not to rest satisfied with a light and superficial knowledge, nor quickly to assent to things commonly spoken of: whom also I must thank that ever I lighted upon Epictetus his Hypomnemata, or moral commentaries and common factions:
sentences: to read with diligence not to rest satisfied with light and superficial knowledge nor quickly to assent to things commonly spoken of whom also must thank that ever lighted upon epictetus his hypomnemata or moral commentaries and common factions

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: which also he gave me of his own.
sentences: which also he gave me of his own

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: From Apollonius, true liberty, and unvariable steadfastness, and not to regard anything at all, though never so little, but right and reason: and always, whether in the sharpest pains, or after the loss of a child, or in long diseases, to be still the same man; who also was a present and visible example unto me, that it was possible for the same man to be both vehement and remiss: a man not subject to be vexed, and offended with the incapacity of his scholars and auditors in his lectures and expositions; and a true pattern of a man who of all his good gifts and faculties, least esteemed in himself, that his excellent skill and ability to teach and persuade others the common theorems and maxims of the Stoic philosophy.
sentences: from apollonius true liberty and unvariable steadfastness and not to regard anything at all though never so little but right and reason and always whether in the sharpest pains or after the loss of child or in long diseases to be still the same man who also was present and visible example unto me that it was possible for the same man to be both vehement and remiss man not subject to be vexed and offended with the incapacity of his scholars and auditors in his lectures and expositions and true pattern of man who of all his good gifts and faculties least esteemed in himself that his excellent skill and ability to teach and persuade others the common theorems and maxims of the stoic philosophy

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of him also I learned how to receive favours and kindnesses (as commonly they are accounted:) from friends, so that I might not become obnoxious unto them, for them, nor more yielding upon occasion, than in right
sentences: of him also learned how to receive favours and kindnesses as commonly they are accounted from friends so that might not become obnoxious unto them for them nor more yielding upon occasion than in right

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: I ought; and yet so that I should not pass them neither, as an unsensible and unthankful man.
sentences: ought and yet so that should not pass them neither as an unsensible and unthankful man

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of Sextus, mildness and the pattern of a family governed with paternal affection; and a purpose to live according to nature: to be grave without affectation: to observe carefully the several dispositions of my friends, not to be offended with idiots, nor unseasonably to set upon those that are carried with the vulgar opinions, with the theorems, and tenets of philosophers: his conversation being an example how a man might accommodate himself to all men and companies; so that though his company were sweeter and more pleasing than any flatterer's cogging and fawning; yet was it at the same time most respected and reverenced: who also had a proper happiness and faculty, rationally and methodically to find out, and set in order all necessary determinations and instructions for a man's life.
sentences: of sextus mildness and the pattern of family governed with paternal affection and purpose to live according to nature to be grave without affectation to observe carefully the several dispositions of my friends not to be offended with idiots nor unseasonably to set upon those that are carried with the vulgar opinions with the theorems and tenets of philosophers his conversation being an example how man might accommodate himself to all men and companies so that though his company were sweeter and more pleasing than any flatterer cogging and fawning yet was it at the same time most respected and reverenced who also had proper happiness and faculty rationally and methodically to find out and set in order all necessary determinations and instructions for man life

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: A man without ever the least appearance of anger, or any other passion; able at the same time most exactly to observe the Stoic Apathia, or unpassionateness, and yet to be most tender hearted:
sentences: man without ever the least appearance of anger or any other passion able at the same time most exactly to observe the stoic apathia or unpassionateness and yet to be most tender hearted

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: ever of good credit; and yet almost without any noise, or rumour: very learned, and yet making little show.
sentences: ever of good credit and yet almost without any noise or rumour very learned and yet making little show

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: From Alexander the Grammarian, to be un reprovable myself, and not reproachfully to reprehend any man for a barbarism, or a solecism, or any false pronunciation, but dextrously by way of answer, or testimony, or confirmation of the same matter (taking no notice of the word) to utter it as it should have been spoken; or by some other such close and indirect admonition, handsomely and civilly to tell him of it.
sentences: from alexander the grammarian to be un reprovable myself and not reproachfully to reprehend any man for barbarism or solecism or any false pronunciation but dextrously by way of answer or testimony or confirmation of the same matter taking no notice of the word to utter it as it should have been spoken or by some other such close and indirect admonition handsomely and civilly to tell him of it

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of Fronto, to how much envy and fraud and hypocrisy the state of a tyrannous king is subject unto, and how they who are commonly called Eupatridas Gk.
sentences: of fronto to how much envy and fraud and hypocrisy the state of tyrannous king is subject unto and how they who are commonly called eupatridas gk

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: ie nobly born, are in some sort incapable, or void of natural affection.
sentences: ie nobly born are in some sort incapable or void of natural affection

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of Alexander the Platonic, not often nor without great necessity to say, or to write to any man in a letter, 'I am not at leisure'; nor in this manner still to put off those duties, which we owe to our friends and acquaintances (to every one in his kind) under pretence of urgent affairs.
sentences: of alexander the platonic not often nor without great necessity to say or to write to any man in letter am not at leisure nor in this manner still to put off those duties which we owe to our friends and acquaintances to every one in his kind under pretence of urgent affairs

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of Catulus, not to contemn any friend's expostulation, though unjust, but to strive to reduce him to his former disposition: freely and heartily to speak well of all my masters upon any occasion, as it is reported of Domitius, and Athenodotus: and to love my children with true affection.
sentences: of catulus not to contemn any friend expostulation though unjust but to strive to reduce him to his former disposition freely and heartily to speak well of all my masters upon any occasion as it is reported of domitius and athenodotus and to love my children with true affection

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: From my brother Severus, to be kind and loving to all them of my house and family; by whom also I came to the knowledge of Thrasea and Helvidius, and Cato, and Dio, and Brutus.
sentences: from my brother severus to be kind and loving to all them of my house and family by whom also came to the knowledge of thrasea and helvidius and cato and dio and brutus

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: He it was also that did put me in the first conceit and desire of an equal commonwealth, administered by justice and equality; and of a kingdom wherein should be regarded nothing more than the good and welfare of the subjects.
sentences: he it was also that did put me in the first conceit and desire of an equal commonwealth administered by justice and equality and of kingdom wherein should be regarded nothing more than the good and welfare of the subjects

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of him also, to observe a constant tenor, (not interrupted, with any other cares and distractions,) in the study and esteem of philosophy: to be bountiful and liberal in the largest measure; always to hope the best; and to be confident that my friends love me.
sentences: of him also to observe constant tenor not interrupted with any other cares and distractions in the study and esteem of philosophy to be bountiful and liberal in the largest measure always to hope the best and to be confident that my friends love me

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: In whom I moreover observed open dealing towards those whom he reproved at any time, and that his friends might without all doubt or much observation know what he would, or would not, so open and plain was he.
sentences: in whom moreover observed open dealing towards those whom he reproved at any time and that his friends might without all doubt or much observation know what he would or would not so open and plain was he

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: From Claudius Maximus, in all things to endeavour to have power of myself, and in nothing to be carried about; to be cheerful and courageous in all sudden chances and accidents, as in sicknesses: to love mildness, and moderation, and gravity: and to do my business, whatsoever it be, thoroughly, and without querulousness.
sentences: from claudius maximus in all things to endeavour to have power of myself and in nothing to be carried about to be cheerful and courageous in all sudden chances and accidents as in sicknesses to love mildness and moderation and gravity and to do my business whatsoever it be thoroughly and without querulousness

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever he said, all men believed him that as he spake, so he thought, and whatsoever he did, that he did it with a good intent.
sentences: whatsoever he said all men believed him that as he spake so he thought and whatsoever he did that he did it with good intent

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: His manner was, never to wonder at anything; never to be in haste, and yet never slow: nor to be perplexed, or dejected, or at any time unseemly, or excessively to laugh: nor to be angry, or suspicious, but ever ready to do good, and to forgive, and to speak truth; and all this, as one that seemed rather of himself to have been straight and right, than ever to have been rectified or redressed; neither was there any man that ever thought himself undervalued by him, or that could find in his heart, to think himself a better man than he.
sentences: his manner was never to wonder at anything never to be in haste and yet never slow nor to be perplexed or dejected or at any time unseemly or excessively to laugh nor to be angry or suspicious but ever ready to do good and to forgive and to speak truth and all this as one that seemed rather of himself to have been straight and right than ever to have been rectified or redressed neither was there any man that ever thought himself undervalued by him or that could find in his heart to think himself better man than he

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: He would also be very pleasant and gracious.
sentences: he would also be very pleasant and gracious

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: In my father, I observed his meekness; his constancy without wavering in those things, which after a due examination and deliberation, he had determined.
sentences: in my father observed his meekness his constancy without wavering in those things which after due examination and deliberation he had determined

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: How free from all vanity he carried himself in matter of honour and dignity, (as they are esteemed:)
sentences: how free from all vanity he carried himself in matter of honour and dignity as they are esteemed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: his laboriousness and assiduity, his readiness to hear any man, that had aught to say tending to any common good: how generally and impartially he would give every man his due; his skill and knowledge, when rigour or extremity, or when remissness or moderation was in season; how he did abstain from all unchaste love of youths; his moderate condescending to other men's occasions as an ordinary man, neither absolutely requiring of his friends, that they should wait upon him at his ordinary meals, nor that they should of necessity accompany him in his journeys; and that whensoever any business upon some necessary occasions was to be put off and omitted before it could be ended, he was ever found when he went about it again, the same man that he was before.
sentences: his laboriousness and assiduity his readiness to hear any man that had aught to say tending to any common good how generally and impartially he would give every man his due his skill and knowledge when rigour or extremity or when remissness or moderation was in season how he did abstain from all unchaste love of youths his moderate condescending to other men occasions as an ordinary man neither absolutely requiring of his friends that they should wait upon him at his ordinary meals nor that they should of necessity accompany him in his journeys and that whensoever any business upon some necessary occasions was to be put off and omitted before it could be ended he was ever found when he went about it again the same man that he was before

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: His accurate examination of things in consultations, and patient hearing of others.
sentences: his accurate examination of things in consultations and patient hearing of others

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: He would not hastily give over the search of the matter, as one easy to be satisfied with sudden notions and apprehensions.
sentences: he would not hastily give over the search of the matter as one easy to be satisfied with sudden notions and apprehensions

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: His care to preserve his friends; how neither at any time he would carry himself towards them with disdainful neglect, and grow weary of them; nor yet at any time be madly fond of them.
sentences: his care to preserve his friends how neither at any time he would carry himself towards them with disdainful neglect and grow weary of them nor yet at any time be madly fond of them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: His contented mind in all things, his cheerful countenance, his care to foresee things afar off, and to take order for the least, without any noise or clamour.
sentences: his contented mind in all things his cheerful countenance his care to foresee things afar off and to take order for the least without any noise or clamour

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Moreover how all acclamations and flattery were repressed by him: how carefully he observed all things necessary to the government, and kept an account of the common expenses, and how patiently he did abide that he was reprehended by some for this his strict and rigid kind of dealing.
sentences: moreover how all acclamations and flattery were repressed by him how carefully he observed all things necessary to the government and kept an account of the common expenses and how patiently he did abide that he was reprehended by some for this his strict and rigid kind of dealing

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: How he was neither a superstitious worshipper of the gods, nor an ambitious pleaser of men, or studious of popular applause; but sober in all things, and everywhere observant of that which was fitting; no affecter of novelties: in those things which conduced to his ease and convenience, (plenty whereof his fortune did afford him,) without pride and bragging, yet with all freedom and liberty:
sentences: how he was neither superstitious worshipper of the gods nor an ambitious pleaser of men or studious of popular applause but sober in all things and everywhere observant of that which was fitting no affecter of novelties in those things which conduced to his ease and convenience plenty whereof his fortune did afford him without pride and bragging yet with all freedom and liberty

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: so that as he did freely enjoy them without any anxiety or affectation when they were present; so when absent, he found no want of them.
sentences: so that as he did freely enjoy them without any anxiety or affectation when they were present so when absent he found no want of them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Moreover, that he was never commended by any man, as either a learned acute man, or an obsequious officious man, or a fine orator; but as a ripe mature man, a perfect sound man; one that could not endure to be flattered; able to govern both himself and others.
sentences: moreover that he was never commended by any man as either learned acute man or an obsequious officious man or fine orator but as ripe mature man perfect sound man one that could not endure to be flattered able to govern both himself and others

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Moreover, how much he did honour all true philosophers, without upbraiding those that were not so; his sociableness, his gracious and delightful conversation, but never unto satiety; his care of his body within bounds and measure, not as one that desired to live long, or over studious of neatness, and elegancy; and yet not as one that did not regard it: so that through his own care and providence, he seldom needed any inward physic, or outward applications: but especially how ingeniously he would yield to any that had obtained any peculiar faculty, as either eloquence, or the knowledge of the laws, or of ancient customs, or the like; and how he concurred with them, in his best care and endeavour that every one of them might in his kind, for that wherein he excelled, be regarded and esteemed: and although he did all things carefully after the ancient customs of his forefathers, yet even of this was he not desirous that men should take notice, that he did imitate ancient customs.
sentences: moreover how much he did honour all true philosophers without upbraiding those that were not so his sociableness his gracious and delightful conversation but never unto satiety his care of his body within bounds and measure not as one that desired to live long or over studious of neatness and elegancy and yet not as one that did not regard it so that through his own care and providence he seldom needed any inward physic or outward applications but especially how ingeniously he would yield to any that had obtained any peculiar faculty as either eloquence or the knowledge of the laws or of ancient customs or the like and how he concurred with them in his best care and endeavour that every one of them might in his kind for that wherein he excelled be regarded and esteemed and although he did all things carefully after the ancient customs of his forefathers yet even of this was he not desirous that men should take notice that he did imitate ancient customs

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Again, how he was not easily moved and tossed up and down, but loved to be constant, both in the same places and businesses; and how after his great fits of headache he would return fresh and vigorous to his wonted affairs.
sentences: again how he was not easily moved and tossed up and down but loved to be constant both in the same places and businesses and how after his great fits of headache he would return fresh and vigorous to his wonted affairs

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Again, that secrets he neither had many, nor often, and such only as concerned public matters: his discretion and moderation, in exhibiting of the public sights and shows for the pleasure and pastime of the people: in public buildings.
sentences: again that secrets he neither had many nor often and such only as concerned public matters his discretion and moderation in exhibiting of the public sights and shows for the pleasure and pastime of the people in public buildings

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: congiaries, and the like.
sentences: congiaries and the like

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: In all these things, having a respect unto men only as men, and to the equity of the things themselves, and not unto the glory that might follow.
sentences: in all these things having respect unto men only as men and to the equity of the things themselves and not unto the glory that might follow

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Never wont to use the baths at unseasonable hours; no builder; never curious, or solicitous, either about his meat, or about the workmanship, or colour of his clothes, or about anything that belonged to external beauty.
sentences: never wont to use the baths at unseasonable hours no builder never curious or solicitous either about his meat or about the workmanship or colour of his clothes or about anything that belonged to external beauty

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: In all his conversation, far from all inhumanity, all boldness, and incivility, all greediness and impetuosity; never doing anything with such earnestness, and intention, that a man could say of him, that he did sweat about it: but contrariwise, all things distinctly, as at leisure; without trouble; orderly, soundly, and agreeably.
sentences: in all his conversation far from all inhumanity all boldness and incivility all greediness and impetuosity never doing anything with such earnestness and intention that man could say of him that he did sweat about it but contrariwise all things distinctly as at leisure without trouble orderly soundly and agreeably

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: A man might have applied that to him, which is recorded of Socrates, that he knew how to want, and to enjoy those things, in the want whereof, most men show themselves weak; and in the fruition, intemperate: but to hold out firm and constant, and to keep within the compass of true moderation and sobriety in either estate, is proper to a man, who hath a perfect and invincible soul; such as he showed himself in the sickness of Maximus.
sentences: man might have applied that to him which is recorded of socrates that he knew how to want and to enjoy those things in the want whereof most men show themselves weak and in the fruition intemperate but to hold out firm and constant and to keep within the compass of true moderation and sobriety in either estate is proper to man who hath perfect and invincible soul such as he showed himself in the sickness of maximus

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: From the gods I received that I had good grandfathers, and parents, a good sister, good masters, gooddomestics, loving kinsmen, almost all that I have; and that I never through haste and rashness transgressed against any of them, notwithstanding that my disposition was such, as that such a thing (if occasion had been) might very well have been committed by me, but that It was the mercy of the gods, to prevent such a concurring of matters and occasions, as might make me to incur this blame.
sentences: from the gods received that had good grandfathers and parents good sister good masters gooddomestics loving kinsmen almost all that have and that never through haste and rashness transgressed against any of them notwithstanding that my disposition was such as that such thing if occasion had been might very well have been committed by me but that it was the mercy of the gods to prevent such concurring of matters and occasions as might make me to incur this blame

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: That I was not long brought up by the concubine of my father; that I preserved the flower of my youth.
sentences: that was not long brought up by the concubine of my father that preserved the flower of my youth

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: That I took not upon me to be a man before my time, but rather put it off longer than I needed.
sentences: that took not upon me to be man before my time but rather put it off longer than needed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: That I lived under the government of my lord and father, who would take away from me all pride and vainglory, and reduce me to that conceit and opinion that it was not impossible for a prince to live in the court without a troop of guards and followers, extraordinary apparel, such and such torches and statues, and other like particulars of state and magnificence; but that a man may reduce and contract himself almost to the state of a private man, and yet for all that not to become the more base and remiss in those public matters and affairs, wherein power and authority is requisite.
sentences: that lived under the government of my lord and father who would take away from me all pride and vainglory and reduce me to that conceit and opinion that it was not impossible for prince to live in the court without troop of guards and followers extraordinary apparel such and such torches and statues and other like particulars of state and magnificence but that man may reduce and contract himself almost to the state of private man and yet for all that not to become the more base and remiss in those public matters and affairs wherein power and authority is requisite

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But I that understand the nature of that which is good, that it only is to be desired, and of that which is bad, that it only is truly odious and shameful: who know moreover, that this transgressor, whosoever he be, is my kinsman, not by the same blood and seed, but by participation of the same reason, and of the same divine particle; How can I either be hurt by any of those, since it is not in their power to make me incur anything that is truly reproachful?
sentences: but that understand the nature of that which is good that it only is to be desired and of that which is bad that it only is truly odious and shameful who know moreover that this transgressor whosoever he be is my kinsman not by the same blood and seed but by participation of the same reason and of the same divine particle how can either be hurt by any of those since it is not in their power to make me incur anything that is truly reproachful

author: Marcus Aurelius
