title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: for we are all born to be fellow workers, as the feet, the hands, and the eyelids; as the rows of the upper and under teeth: for such therefore to be in opposition, is against nature; and what is it to chafe at, and to be averse from, but to be in opposition?.
sentences: for we are all born to be fellow workers as the feet the hands and the eyelids as the rows of the upper and under teeth for such therefore to be in opposition is against nature and what is it to chafe at and to be averse from but to be in opposition

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever I am, is either flesh, or life, or that which we commonly call the mistress and overruling part of man; reason.
sentences: whatsoever am is either flesh or life or that which we commonly call the mistress and overruling part of man reason

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Away with thy books, suffer not thy mind any more to be distracted, and carried to and fro; for it will not be; but as even now ready to die, think little of thy flesh: blood, bones, and a skin; a pretty piece of knit and twisted work, consisting of nerves, veins and arteries; think no more of it, than so.
sentences: away with thy books suffer not thy mind any more to be distracted and carried to and fro for it will not be but as even now ready to die think little of thy flesh blood bones and skin pretty piece of knit and twisted work consisting of nerves veins and arteries think no more of it than so

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as for thy life, consider what it is; a wind; not one constant wind neither, but every moment of an hour let out, and sucked in again.
sentences: and as for thy life consider what it is wind not one constant wind neither but every moment of an hour let out and sucked in again

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The third, is thy ruling part; and here consider; Thou art an old man; suffer not that excellent part to be brought in subjection, and to become slavish: suffer it not to be drawn up and down with unreasonable and unsociable lusts and motions, as it were with wires and nerves; suffer it not any more, either to repine at anything now present, or to fear and fly anything to come, which the destiny hath appointed thee.
sentences: the third is thy ruling part and here consider thou art an old man suffer not that excellent part to be brought in subjection and to become slavish suffer it not to be drawn up and down with unreasonable and unsociable lusts and motions as it were with wires and nerves suffer it not any more either to repine at anything now present or to fear and fly anything to come which the destiny hath appointed thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever proceeds from the gods immediately, that any man will grant totally depends from their divine providence.
sentences: whatsoever proceeds from the gods immediately that any man will grant totally depends from their divine providence

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As for those things that are commonly said to happen by fortune, even those must be conceived to have dependence from nature, or from that first and general connection, and concatenation of all those things, which more apparently by the divine providence are administered and brought to pass.
sentences: as for those things that are commonly said to happen by fortune even those must be conceived to have dependence from nature or from that first and general connection and concatenation of all those things which more apparently by the divine providence are administered and brought to pass

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: All things flow from thence: and whatsoever it is that is, is both necessary, and conducing to the whole (part of which thou art), and whatsoever it is that is requisite and necessary for the preservation of the general, must of necessity for every particular nature, be good and behoveful.
sentences: all things flow from thence and whatsoever it is that is is both necessary and conducing to the whole part of which thou art and whatsoever it is that is requisite and necessary for the preservation of the general must of necessity for every particular nature be good and behoveful

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as for the whole, it is preserved, as by the perpetual mutation and conversion of the simple elements one into another, so also by the mutation, and alteration of things mixed and compounded.
sentences: and as for the whole it is preserved as by the perpetual mutation and conversion of the simple elements one into another so also by the mutation and alteration of things mixed and compounded

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: whereof thou art part and of that lord and governor of the world from whom as channel from the spring thou thyself didst flow and that there is but certain limit of time appointed unto thee which if thou shalt not make use of to calm and allay the many distempers of thy soul it will pass away and thou with it and never after return

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Which thou shalt do; if thou shalt go about every action as thy last action, free from all vanity, all passionate and wilful aberration from reason, and from all hypocrisy, and self love, and dislike of those things, which by the fates or appointment of God have happened unto thee.
sentences: which thou shalt do if thou shalt go about every action as thy last action free from all vanity all passionate and wilful aberration from reason and from all hypocrisy and self love and dislike of those things which by the fates or appointment of god have happened unto thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Thou seest that those things, which for a man to hold on in a prosperous course, and to live a divine life, are requisite and necessary, are not many, for the gods will require no more of any man, that shall but keep and observe these things.
sentences: thou seest that those things which for man to hold on in prosperous course and to live divine life are requisite and necessary are not many for the gods will require no more of any man that shall but keep and observe these things

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Every man's happiness depends from himself, but behold thy life is almost at an end, whiles affording thyself no respect, thou dost make thy happiness to consist in the souls, and conceits of other men.
sentences: every man happiness depends from himself but behold thy life is almost at an end whiles affording thyself no respect thou dost make thy happiness to consist in the souls and conceits of other men

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: thou must also take heed of another kind of wandering for they are idle in their actions who toil and labour in this life and have no certain scope to which to direct all their motions and desires

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Theophrastus, where he compares sin with sin (as after a vulgar sense such things I grant may be compared:) says well and like a philosopher, that those sins are greater which are committed through lust, than those which are committed through anger.
sentences: theophrastus where he compares sin with sin as after vulgar sense such things grant may be compared says well and like philosopher that those sins are greater which are committed through lust than those which are committed through anger

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For he that is angry seems with a kind of grief and close contraction of himself, to turn away from reason; but he that sins through lust, being overcome by pleasure, doth in his very sin bewray a more impotent, and unmanlike disposition.
sentences: for he that is angry seems with kind of grief and close contraction of himself to turn away from reason but he that sins through lust being overcome by pleasure doth in his very sin bewray more impotent and unmanlike disposition

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Well then and like a philosopher doth he say, that he of the two is the more to be condemned, that sins with pleasure, than he that sins with grief.
sentences: well then and like philosopher doth he say that he of the two is the more to be condemned that sins with pleasure than he that sins with grief

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For indeed this latter may seem first to have been wronged, and so in some manner through grief thereof to have been forced to be angry, whereas he who through lust doth commit anything, did of himself merely resolve upon that action.
sentences: for indeed this latter may seem first to have been wronged and so in some manner through grief thereof to have been forced to be angry whereas he who through lust doth commit anything did of himself merely resolve upon that action

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever thou dost affect, whatsoever thou dost project, so do, and so project all, as one who, for aught thou knowest,

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: may at this very present depart out of this life.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as for death, if there be any gods, it is no grievous thing to leave the society of men.
sentences: and as for death if there be any gods it is no grievous thing to leave the society of men

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The gods will do thee no hurt, thou mayest be sure.
sentences: the gods will do thee no hurt thou mayest be sure

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But if it be so that there be no gods, or that they take no care of the world, why should I desire to live in a world void of gods, and of all divine providence?
sentences: but if it be so that there be no gods or that they take no care of the world why should desire to live in world void of gods and of all divine providence

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But gods there be certainly, and they take care for the world; and as for those things which be truly evil, as vice and wickedness, such things they have put in a man's own power, that he might avoid them if he would: and had there been anything besides that had been truly bad and evil, they would have had a care of that also, that a man might have avoided it.
sentences: but gods there be certainly and they take care for the world and as for those things which be truly evil as vice and wickedness such things they have put in man own power that he might avoid them if he would and had there been anything besides that had been truly bad and evil they would have had care of that also that man might have avoided it

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But why should that be thought to hurt and prejudice a man's life in this world, which cannot any ways make man himself the better, or the worse in his own person?
sentences: but why should that be thought to hurt and prejudice man life in this world which cannot any ways make man himself the better or the worse in his own person

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Neither must we think that the nature of the universe did either through ignorance pass these things, or if not as ignorant of them, yet as unable either to prevent, or better to order and dispose them.
sentences: neither must we think that the nature of the universe did either through ignorance pass these things or if not as ignorant of them yet as unable either to prevent or better to order and dispose them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: It cannot be that she through want either of power or skill, should have committed such a thing, so as to suffer all things both good and bad, equally and promiscuously, to happen unto all both good and bad.
sentences: it cannot be that she through want either of power or skill should have committed such thing so as to suffer all things both good and bad equally and promiscuously to happen unto all both good and bad

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As for life therefore, and death, honour and dishonour, labour and pleasure, riches and poverty, all these things happen unto men indeed, both good and bad, equally; but as things which of themselves are neither good nor bad; because of themselves, neither shameful nor praiseworthy.
sentences: as for life therefore and death honour and dishonour labour and pleasure riches and poverty all these things happen unto men indeed both good and bad equally but as things which of themselves are neither good nor bad because of themselves neither shameful nor praiseworthy

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Consider how quickly all things are dissolved and resolved: the bodies and substances themselves, into the matter and substance of the world: and their memories into the general age and time of the world.
sentences: consider how quickly all things are dissolved and resolved the bodies and substances themselves into the matter and substance of the world and their memories into the general age and time of the world

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Consider the nature of all worldly sensible things; of those especially, which either ensnare by pleasure, or for their irksomeness are dreadful, or for their outward lustre and show are in great esteem and request, how vile and contemptible, how base and corruptible, how destitute of all true life and being they are.
sentences: consider the nature of all worldly sensible things of those especially which either ensnare by pleasure or for their irksomeness are dreadful or for their outward lustre and show are in great esteem and request how vile and contemptible how base and corruptible how destitute of all true life and being they are

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: It is the part of a man endowed with a good understanding faculty, to consider what they themselves are in very deed, from whose bare conceits and voices, honour and credit do proceed: as also what it is to die, and how if a man shall consider this by itself alone, to die, and separate from it in his mind all those things which with it usually represent themselves unto us, he can conceive of it no otherwise, than as of a work of nature, and he that fears any work of nature, is a very child.
sentences: it is the part of man endowed with good understanding faculty to consider what they themselves are in very deed from whose bare conceits and voices honour and credit do proceed as also what it is to die and how if man shall consider this by itself alone to die and separate from it in his mind all those things which with it usually represent themselves unto us he can conceive of it no otherwise than as of work of nature and he that fears any work of nature is very child

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Now death, it is not only a work of nature, but also conducing to nature.
sentences: now death it is not only work of nature but also conducing to nature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Consider with thyself how man, and by what part of his, is joined unto God, and how that part of man is affected, when it is said to be diffused.
sentences: consider with thyself how man and by what part of his is joined unto god and how that part of man is affected when it is said to be diffused

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: There is nothing more wretched than that soul, which in a kind of circuit compasseth all things, searching (as he saith) even the very depths of the earth; and by all signs and conjectures prying into the very thoughts of other men's souls; and yet of this, is not sensible, that it is sufficient for a man to apply himself wholly, and to confine all his thoughts and cares to the tendance of that spirit which is within him, and truly and really to serve him.
sentences: there is nothing more wretched than that soul which in kind of circuit compasseth all things searching as he saith even the very depths of the earth and by all signs and conjectures prying into the very thoughts of other men souls and yet of this is not sensible that it is sufficient for man to apply himself wholly and to confine all his thoughts and cares to the tendance of that spirit which is within him and truly and really to serve him

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: His service doth consist in this, that a man keep himself pure from all violent passion and evil affection, from all rashness and vanity, and from all manner of discontent, either in regard of the gods or men.
sentences: his service doth consist in this that man keep himself pure from all violent passion and evil affection from all rashness and vanity and from all manner of discontent either in regard of the gods or men

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For indeed whatsoever proceeds from the gods, deserves respect for their worth and excellency; and whatsoever proceeds from men, as they are our kinsmen, should by us be entertained, with love, always; sometimes, as proceeding from their ignorance, of that which is truly good and bad, (a blindness no less, than that by which we are not able to discern between white and black:) with a kind of pity and compassion also.
sentences: for indeed whatsoever proceeds from the gods deserves respect for their worth and excellency and whatsoever proceeds from men as they are our kinsmen should by us be entertained with love always sometimes as proceeding from their ignorance of that which is truly good and bad blindness no less than that by which we are not able to discern between white and black with kind of pity and compassion also

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If thou shouldst live three thousand, or as many as ten thousands of years, yet remember this
sentences: if thou shouldst live three thousand or as many as ten thousands of years yet remember this

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: , that man can part with no life properly, save with that little part of life, which he now lives: and that which he lives, is no other, than that which at every instant he parts with.
sentences: that man can part with no life properly save with that little part of life which he now lives and that which he lives is no other than that which at every instant he parts with

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: That then which is longest of duration, and that which is shortest, come both to one effect.
sentences: that then which is longest of duration and that which is shortest come both to one effect

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For although in regard of that which is already past there may be some inequality, yet that time which is now present and in being, is equal unto all men.
sentences: for although in regard of that which is already past there may be some inequality yet that time which is now present and in being is equal unto all men

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And that being it which we part with whensoever we die, it doth manifestly appear, that it can be but a moment of time, that we then part with.
sentences: and that being it which we part with whensoever we die it doth manifestly appear that it can be but moment of time that we then part with

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For as for that which is either past or to come, a man cannot be said properly to part with it.
sentences: for as for that which is either past or to come man cannot be said properly to part with it

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For how should a man part with that which he hath not?
sentences: for how should man part with that which he hath not

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: These two things therefore thou must remember.
sentences: these two things therefore thou must remember

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: First, that all things in the world from all eternity, by a perpetual revolution of the same times and things ever continued and renewed, are of one kind and nature; so that whether for a hundred or two hundred years only, or for an infinite space of time, a man see those things which are still the same, it can be no matter of great moment.
sentences: first that all things in the world from all eternity by perpetual revolution of the same times and things ever continued and renewed are of one kind and nature so that whether for hundred or two hundred years only or for an infinite space of time man see those things which are still the same it can be no matter of great moment

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And secondly, that that life which any the longest liver, or the shortest liver parts with, is for length and duration the very same, for that only which is present, is that, which either of them can lose, as being that only which they have; for that which he hath not, no man can truly be said to lose.
sentences: and secondly that that life which any the longest liver or the shortest liver parts with is for length and duration the very same for that only which is present is that which either of them can lose as being that only which they have for that which he hath not no man can truly be said to lose

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Remember that all is but opinion and conceit, for those things are plain and apparent, which were spoken unto Monimus the Cynic; and as plain and apparent is the use that may be made of those things, if that which is true and serious in them, be received as well as that which is sweet and pleasing.
sentences: remember that all is but opinion and conceit for those things are plain and apparent which were spoken unto monimus the cynic and as plain and apparent is the use that may be made of those things if that which is true and serious in them be received as well as that which is sweet and pleasing

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: A man's soul doth wrong and disrespect itself first and especially, when as much as in itself lies it becomes an aposteme, and as it were an excrescency of the world, for to be grieved and displeased with anything that happens in the world, is direct apostacy from the nature of the universe; part of which, all particular natures of the world, are.
sentences: man soul doth wrong and disrespect itself first and especially when as much as in itself lies it becomes an aposteme and as it were an excrescency of the world for to be grieved and displeased with anything that happens in the world is direct apostacy from the nature of the universe part of which all particular natures of the world are

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Secondly, when she either is averse from any man, or led by contrary desires or affections, tending to his hurt and prejudice; such as are the souls of them that are angry.
sentences: secondly when she either is averse from any man or led by contrary desires or affections tending to his hurt and prejudice such as are the souls of them that are angry

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Thirdly, when she is overcome by any pleasure or pain.
sentences: thirdly when she is overcome by any pleasure or pain

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Fourthly, when she doth dissemble, and covertly and falsely either doth or saith anything.
sentences: fourthly when she doth dissemble and covertly and falsely either doth or saith anything

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Fifthly, when she doth either affect or endeavour anything to no certain end, but rashly and without due ratiocination and consideration, how consequent or inconsequent it is to the common end.
sentences: fifthly when she doth either affect or endeavour anything to no certain end but rashly and without due ratiocination and consideration how consequent or inconsequent it is to the common end

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For even the least things ought not to be done, without relation unto the end; and the end of the reasonable creatures is, to follow and obey him, who is the reason as it were, and the law of this great city, and ancient commonwealth.
sentences: for even the least things ought not to be done without relation unto the end and the end of the reasonable creatures is to follow and obey him who is the reason as it were and the law of this great city and ancient commonwealth

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The time of a man's life is as a point; the substance of it ever flowing, the sense obscure; and the whole composition of the body tending to corruption.
sentences: the time of man life is as point the substance of it ever flowing the sense obscure and the whole composition of the body tending to corruption

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: His soul is restless, fortune uncertain, and fame doubtful; to be brief, as a stream so are all things belonging to the body; as a dream, or as a smoke, so are all that belong unto the soul.
sentences: his soul is restless fortune uncertain and fame doubtful to be brief as stream so are all things belonging to the body as dream or as smoke so are all that belong unto the soul

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Our life is a warfare, and a mere pilgrimage.
sentences: our life is warfare and mere pilgrimage

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Fame after life is no better than oblivion.
sentences: fame after life is no better than oblivion

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: What is it then that will adhere and follow?
sentences: what is it then that will adhere and follow

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Only one thing, philosophy.
sentences: only one thing philosophy

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And philosophy doth consist in this, for a man to preserve that spirit which is within him, from all manner of contumelies and injuries, and above all pains or pleasures; never to do anything either rashly, or feignedly, or hypocritically: wholly to depend from himself and his own proper actions: all things that happen unto him to embrace contentedly, as coming from Him from whom he himself also came; and above all things, with all meekness and a calm cheerfulness, to expect death, as being nothing else but the resolution of those elements, of which every creature is composed.
sentences: and philosophy doth consist in this for man to preserve that spirit which is within him from all manner of contumelies and injuries and above all pains or pleasures never to do anything either rashly or feignedly or hypocritically wholly to depend from himself and his own proper actions all things that happen unto him to embrace contentedly as coming from him from whom he himself also came and above all things with all meekness and calm cheerfulness to expect death as being nothing else but the resolution of those elements of which every creature is composed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And if the elements themselves suffer nothing by this their perpetual conversion of one into another, that dissolution, and alteration, which is so common unto all, why should it be feared by any?
sentences: and if the elements themselves suffer nothing by this their perpetual conversion of one into another that dissolution and alteration which is so common unto all why should it be feared by any

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Is not this according to nature?
sentences: is not this according to nature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But nothing that is according to nature can be evil, whilst I was at Carnuntzim.
sentences: but nothing that is according to nature can be evil whilst was at carnuntzim

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: A man must not only consider how daily his life wasteth and decreaseth, but this also, that if he live long, he cannot be certain, whether his understanding shall continue so able and sufficient, for either discreet consideration, in matter of businesses; or for contemplation: it being the thing, whereon true knowledge of things both divine and human, doth depend.
sentences: man must not only consider how daily his life wasteth and decreaseth but this also that if he live long he cannot be certain whether his understanding shall continue so able and sufficient for either discreet consideration in matter of businesses or for contemplation it being the thing whereon true knowledge of things both divine and human doth depend

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For if once he shall begin to dote, his respiration, nutrition, his imaginative, and appetitive, and other natural faculties, may still continue the same: he shall find no want of them.
sentences: for if once he shall begin to dote his respiration nutrition his imaginative and appetitive and other natural faculties may still continue the same he shall find no want of them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But how to make that right use of himself that he should, how to observe exactly in all things that which is right and just, how to redress and rectify all wrong, or sudden apprehensions and imaginations, and even of this particular, whether he should live any longer or no, to consider duly; for all such things, wherein the best strength and vigour of the mind is most requisite; his power and ability will be past and gone.
sentences: but how to make that right use of himself that he should how to observe exactly in all things that which is right and just how to redress and rectify all wrong or sudden apprehensions and imaginations and even of this particular whether he should live any longer or no to consider duly for all such things wherein the best strength and vigour of the mind is most requisite his power and ability will be past and gone

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Thou must hasten therefore; not only because thou art every day nearer unto death than other, but also because that intellective faculty in thee, whereby thou art enabled to know the true nature of things, and to order all thy actions by that knowledge, doth daily waste and decay: or, may fail thee before thou die.
sentences: thou must hasten therefore not only because thou art every day nearer unto death than other but also because that intellective faculty in thee whereby thou art enabled to know the true nature of things and to order all thy actions by that knowledge doth daily waste and decay or may fail thee before thou die

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: This also thou must observe,
sentences: this also thou must observe

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: that whatsoever it is that naturally doth happen to things natural, hath somewhat in itself that is pleasing and delightful: as a great loaf when it is baked, some parts of it cleave as it were, and part asunder, and make the crust of it rugged and unequal, and yet those parts of it, though in some sort it be against the art and intention of baking itself, that they are thus cleft and parted, which should have been and were first made all even and uniform

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: , they become it well nevertheless, and have a certain peculiar property, to stir the appetite.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So figs are accounted fairest and ripest then, when they begin to shrink, and wither as it were.
sentences: so figs are accounted fairest and ripest then when they begin to shrink and wither as it were

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So ripe olives, when they are next to putrefaction, then are they in their proper beauty.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The hanging down of grapes the brow of a lion, the froth of a foaming wild boar, and many other like things, though by themselves considered, they are far from any beauty, yet because they happen naturally, they both are comely, and delightful; so
sentences: the hanging down of grapes the brow of lion the froth of foaming wild boar and many other like things though by themselves considered they are far from any beauty yet because they happen naturally they both are comely and delightful so

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: that if a man shall with a profound mind and apprehension, consider all things in the world, even among all those things which are but mere accessories and natural appendices as it were, there will scarce appear anything unto him, wherein he will not find matter of pleasure and delight.
sentences: that if man shall with profound mind and apprehension consider all things in the world even among all those things which are but mere accessories and natural appendices as it were there will scarce appear anything unto him wherein he will not find matter of pleasure and delight

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So will he behold with as much pleasure the true rictus of wild beasts, as those which by skilful painters and other artificers are imitated.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So will he be able to perceive the proper ripeness and beauty of old age, whether in man or woman: and whatsoever else

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: it is that is beautiful and alluring in whatsoever is, with chaste and continent eyes he will soon find out and discern.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Those and many other things will he discern, not credible unto every one, but unto them only who are truly and familiarly acquainted, both with nature itself, and all natural things.

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Spend not the remnant of thy days in thoughts and fancies concerning other men, when it is not in relation to some common good, when by it thou art hindered from some other better work.
sentences: spend not the remnant of thy days in thoughts and fancies concerning other men when it is not in relation to some common good when by it thou art hindered from some other better work

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: That is, spend not thy time in thinking, what such a man doth, and to what end: what he saith, and what he thinks, and what he is about, and such other things or curiosities, which make a man to rove and wander from the care and observation of that part of himself, which is rational, and overruling.
sentences: that is spend not thy time in thinking what such man doth and to what end what he saith and what he thinks and what he is about and such other things or curiosities which make man to rove and wander from the care and observation of that part of himself which is rational and overruling

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: See therefore in the whole series and connection of thy thoughts, that thou be careful to prevent whatsoever is idle and impertinent: but especially, whatsoever is curious and malicious: and thou
sentences: see therefore in the whole series and connection of thy thoughts that thou be careful to prevent whatsoever is idle and impertinent but especially whatsoever is curious and malicious and thou

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: must use thyself to think only of such things, of which if a man upon a sudden should ask thee, what it is that thou art now thinking, thou mayest answer This, and That, freely and boldly, that so by thy thoughts it may presently appear that in all thee is sincere, and peaceable; as becometh one that is made for society, and regards not pleasures, nor gives way to any voluptuous imaginations at all: free from all contentiousness, envy, and suspicion, and from whatsoever else thou wouldest blush to confess thy thoughts were set upon.
sentences: must use thyself to think only of such things of which if man upon sudden should ask thee what it is that thou art now thinking thou mayest answer this and that freely and boldly that so by thy thoughts it may presently appear that in all thee is sincere and peaceable as becometh one that is made for society and regards not pleasures nor gives way to any voluptuous imaginations at all free from all contentiousness envy and suspicion and from whatsoever else thou wouldest blush to confess thy thoughts were set upon

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: He that is such, is he surely that doth not put off to lay hold on that which is best indeed, a very priest and minister of the gods, well acquainted and in good correspondence with him especially that is seated and placed within himself, as in a temple and sacrary: to whom also he keeps and preserves himself unspotted by pleasure, undaunted by pain; free from any manner of wrong, or contumely, by himself offered unto himself: not capable of any evil from others: a wrestler of the best sort, and for the highest prize, that he may not be cast down by any passion or affection of his own; deeply dyed and drenched in righteousness, embracing and accepting with his whole heart whatsoever
sentences: he that is such is he surely that doth not put off to lay hold on that which is best indeed very priest and minister of the gods well acquainted and in good correspondence with him especially that is seated and placed within himself as in temple and sacrary to whom also he keeps and preserves himself unspotted by pleasure undaunted by pain free from any manner of wrong or contumely by himself offered unto himself not capable of any evil from others wrestler of the best sort and for the highest prize that he may not be cast down by any passion or affection of his own deeply dyed and drenched in righteousness embracing and accepting with his whole heart whatsoever

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: either happeneth or is allotted unto him.
sentences: either happeneth or is allotted unto him

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: One who not often, nor without some great necessity tending to some public good, mindeth what any other, either speaks, or doth, or purposeth: for those things only that are in his own power, or that are truly his own, are the objects of his employments, and his thoughts are ever taken up with those things, which of the whole universe are by the fates or Providence destinated and appropriated unto himself.
sentences: one who not often nor without some great necessity tending to some public good mindeth what any other either speaks or doth or purposeth for those things only that are in his own power or that are truly his own are the objects of his employments and his thoughts are ever taken up with those things which of the whole universe are by the fates or providence destinated and appropriated unto himself

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Those things that are his own, and in his own power, he himself takes order, for that they be good: and as for those that happen unto him, he believes them to be so.
sentences: those things that are his own and in his own power he himself takes order for that they be good and as for those that happen unto him he believes them to be so

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For that lot and portion which is assigned to every one, as it is unavoidable and necessary, so is it always profitable.
sentences: for that lot and portion which is assigned to every one as it is unavoidable and necessary so is it always profitable

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: He remembers besides that whatsoever partakes of reason, is akin unto him, and that to care for all men generally, is agreeing to the nature of a man: but as for honour and praise, that they ought not generally to be admitted and accepted of from all, but from such only, who live according to nature.
sentences: he remembers besides that whatsoever partakes of reason is akin unto him and that to care for all men generally is agreeing to the nature of man but as for honour and praise that they ought not generally to be admitted and accepted of from all but from such only who live according to nature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As for them that do not, what manner of men they be at home, or abroad; day or night, how conditioned themselves with what manner of conditions, or with men of what conditions they moil and pass away the time together, he knoweth, and remembers right well, he therefore regards not such praise and approbation, as proceeding from them, who cannot like and approve themselves.
sentences: as for them that do not what manner of men they be at home or abroad day or night how conditioned themselves with what manner of conditions or with men of what conditions they moil and pass away the time together he knoweth and remembers right well he therefore regards not such praise and approbation as proceeding from them who cannot like and approve themselves

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Do nothing against thy will, nor contrary to the community, nor without due examination, nor with reluctancy.
sentences: do nothing against thy will nor contrary to the community nor without due examination nor with reluctancy

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Affect not to set out thy thoughts with curious neat language.
sentences: affect not to set out thy thoughts with curious neat language

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Be neither a great talker, nor a great undertaker.
sentences: be neither great talker nor great undertaker

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Moreover, let thy God that is in thee to rule over thee, find by thee, that he hath to do with a man;
sentences: moreover let thy god that is in thee to rule over thee find by thee that he hath to do with man

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: an aged man; a sociable man; a Roman; a prince; one that hath ordered his life, as one that expecteth, as it were, nothing but the sound of the trumpet, sounding a retreat to depart out of this life with all expedition.
sentences: an aged man sociable man roman prince one that hath ordered his life as one that expecteth as it were nothing but the sound of the trumpet sounding retreat to depart out of this life with all expedition

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: one who for his word or actions neither needs an oath nor any man to be witness

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
