title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Rather like one that is straight of himself, or hath ever been straight, than one that hath been rectified.
sentences: rather like one that is straight of himself or hath ever been straight than one that hath been rectified

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If thou shalt find anything in this mortal life better than righteousness, than truth, temperance, fortitude, and in general better than a mind contented both with those things which according to right and reason she doth, and in those, which without her will and knowledge happen unto thee by the providence; if I say, thou canst find out anything better than this, apply thyself unto it with thy whole heart, and that which is best wheresoever thou dost find it, enjoy freely.
sentences: if thou shalt find anything in this mortal life better than righteousness than truth temperance fortitude and in general better than mind contented both with those things which according to right and reason she doth and in those which without her will and knowledge happen unto thee by the providence if say thou canst find out anything better than this apply thyself unto it with thy whole heart and that which is best wheresoever thou dost find it enjoy freely

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But if nothing thou shalt find worthy to be preferred to that spirit which is within thee;
sentences: but if nothing thou shalt find worthy to be preferred to that spirit which is within thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: if nothing better than to subject unto thee thine own lusts and desires, and not to give way to any fancies or imaginations before thou hast duly considered of them, nothing better than to withdraw thyself (to use Socrates his words) from all sensuality, and submit thyself unto the gods, and to have care of all men in general: if thou shalt find that all other things in comparison of this, are but vile, and of little moment; then give not way to any other thing, which being once though but affected and inclined unto, it will no more be in thy power without all distraction as thou oughtest to prefer and to pursue after that good, which is thine own and thy proper good.
sentences: if nothing better than to subject unto thee thine own lusts and desires and not to give way to any fancies or imaginations before thou hast duly considered of them nothing better than to withdraw thyself to use socrates his words from all sensuality and submit thyself unto the gods and to have care of all men in general if thou shalt find that all other things in comparison of this are but vile and of little moment then give not way to any other thing which being once though but affected and inclined unto it will no more be in thy power without all distraction as thou oughtest to prefer and to pursue after that good which is thine own and thy proper good

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For it is not lawful, that anything that is of another and inferior kind and nature, be it what it will, as either popular applause, or honour, or riches, or pleasures; should be suffered to confront and contest as it were, with that which is rational, and operatively good.
sentences: for it is not lawful that anything that is of another and inferior kind and nature be it what it will as either popular applause or honour or riches or pleasures should be suffered to confront and contest as it were with that which is rational and operatively good

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For all these things, if once though but for a while, they begin to please, they presently prevail, and pervert a man's mind, or turn a man from the right way.
sentences: for all these things if once though but for while they begin to please they presently prevail and pervert man mind or turn man from the right way

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: therefore I say absolutely and freely make choice of that which is best, and stick unto it.
sentences: therefore say absolutely and freely make choice of that which is best and stick unto it

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Now, that they say is best, which is most profitable.
sentences: now that they say is best which is most profitable

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If they mean profitable to man as he is a rational man, stand thou to it, and maintain it; but if they mean profitable, as he is a creature, only reject it; and from this thy tenet and conclusion keep off carefully all plausible shows and colours of external appearance, that thou mayest be able to discern things rightly.
sentences: if they mean profitable to man as he is rational man stand thou to it and maintain it but if they mean profitable as he is creature only reject it and from this thy tenet and conclusion keep off carefully all plausible shows and colours of external appearance that thou mayest be able to discern things rightly

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Never esteem of anything as profitable, which shall ever constrain thee either to break thy faith, or to lose thy modesty; to hate any man, to suspect, to curse, to dissemble, to lust after anything, that requireth the secret of walls or veils.
sentences: never esteem of anything as profitable which shall ever constrain thee either to break thy faith or to lose thy modesty to hate any man to suspect to curse to dissemble to lust after anything that requireth the secret of walls or veils

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But he that preferreth before all things his rational part and spirit, and the sacred mysteries of virtue which issueth from it, he shall never lament and exclaim, never sigh; he shall never want either solitude or company: and which is chiefest of all, he shall live without either desire or fear.
sentences: but he that preferreth before all things his rational part and spirit and the sacred mysteries of virtue which issueth from it he shall never lament and exclaim never sigh he shall never want either solitude or company and which is chiefest of all he shall live without either desire or fear

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as for life, whether for a long or short time he shall enjoy his soul thus compassed about with a body, he is altogether indifferent.
sentences: and as for life whether for long or short time he shall enjoy his soul thus compassed about with body he is altogether indifferent

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For if even now he were to depart, he is as ready for it, as for any other action, which may be performed with modesty and decency.
sentences: for if even now he were to depart he is as ready for it as for any other action which may be performed with modesty and decency

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For all his life long, this is his only care, that his mind may always be occupied in such intentions and objects, as are proper to a rational sociable creature.
sentences: for all his life long this is his only care that his mind may always be occupied in such intentions and objects as are proper to rational sociable creature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: In the mind that is once truly disciplined and purged, thou canst not find anything, either foul or impure, or as it were festered: nothing that is either servile, or affected: no partial tie; no malicious averseness; nothing obnoxious; nothing concealed.
sentences: in the mind that is once truly disciplined and purged thou canst not find anything either foul or impure or as it were festered nothing that is either servile or affected no partial tie no malicious averseness nothing obnoxious nothing concealed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The life of such an one, death can never surprise as imperfect; as of an actor, that should die before he had ended, or the play itself were at an end, a man might speak.
sentences: the life of such an one death can never surprise as imperfect as of an actor that should die before he had ended or the play itself were at an end man might speak

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Use thine opinative faculty with all honour and respect, for in her indeed is all: that thy opinion do not beget in thy understanding anything contrary to either nature, or the proper constitution of a rational creature.
sentences: use thine opinative faculty with all honour and respect for in her indeed is all that thy opinion do not beget in thy understanding anything contrary to either nature or the proper constitution of rational creature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The end and object of a rational constitution is, to do nothing rashly, to be kindly affected towards men, and in all things willingly to submit unto the gods.
sentences: the end and object of rational constitution is to do nothing rashly to be kindly affected towards men and in all things willingly to submit unto the gods

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Casting therefore all other things aside, keep thyself to these few, and remember withal that no man properly can be said to live more than that which is now present, which is but a moment of time.
sentences: casting therefore all other things aside keep thyself to these few and remember withal that no man properly can be said to live more than that which is now present which is but moment of time

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever is besides either is already past, or uncertain.
sentences: whatsoever is besides either is already past or uncertain

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The time therefore that any man doth live, is but a little, and the place where he liveth, is but a very little corner of the earth, and the greatest fame that can remain of a man after his death, even that is but little, and that too, such as it is whilst it is, is by the succession of silly mortal men preserved, who likewise shall shortly die, and even whiles they live know not
sentences: the time therefore that any man doth live is but little and the place where he liveth is but very little corner of the earth and the greatest fame that can remain of man after his death even that is but little and that too such as it is whilst it is is by the succession of silly mortal men preserved who likewise shall shortly die and even whiles they live know not

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: what in very deed they themselves are: and much less can know one, who long before is dead and gone.
sentences: what in very deed they themselves are and much less can know one who long before is dead and gone

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: To these ever present helps and mementoes, let one more be added, ever to make a particular description and delineation as it were of every object that presents itself to thy mind, that thou mayest wholly and throughly contemplate it, in its own proper nature, bare and naked; wholly, and severally; divided into its several parts and quarters: and then by thyself in thy mind, to call both it, and those things of which it doth consist, and in which it shall be resolved, by their own proper true names, and appellations.
sentences: to these ever present helps and mementoes let one more be added ever to make particular description and delineation as it were of every object that presents itself to thy mind that thou mayest wholly and throughly contemplate it in its own proper nature bare and naked wholly and severally divided into its several parts and quarters and then by thyself in thy mind to call both it and those things of which it doth consist and in which it shall be resolved by their own proper true names and appellations

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For there is nothing so effectual to beget true magnanimity, as to be able truly and methodically to examine and consider all things that happen in this life, and so to penetrate into their natures, that at the same time, this also may concur in our apprehensions: what is the true use of it?
sentences: for there is nothing so effectual to beget true magnanimity as to be able truly and methodically to examine and consider all things that happen in this life and so to penetrate into their natures that at the same time this also may concur in our apprehensions what is the true use of it

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: and what is the true nature of this universe, to which it is useful?
sentences: and what is the true nature of this universe to which it is useful

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: how much in regard of the universe may it be esteemed?
sentences: how much in regard of the universe may it be esteemed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: how much in regard of man, a citizen of the supreme city, of which all other cities in the world are as it were but houses and families?.
sentences: how much in regard of man citizen of the supreme city of which all other cities in the world are as it were but houses and families

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: What is this, that now my fancy is set upon?
sentences: what is this that now my fancy is set upon

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: of what things doth it consist?
sentences: of what things doth it consist

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: how long can it last?
sentences: how long can it last

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: which of all the virtues is the proper virtue for this present use?
sentences: which of all the virtues is the proper virtue for this present use

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: as whether meekness, fortitude, truth, faith, sincerity, contentation, or any of the rest?
sentences: as whether meekness fortitude truth faith sincerity contentation or any of the rest

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Of everything therefore thou must use thyself to say, This immediately comes from God, this by that fatal connection, and concatenation of things, or (which almost comes to one) by some coincidental casualty.
sentences: of everything therefore thou must use thyself to say this immediately comes from god this by that fatal connection and concatenation of things or which almost comes to one by some coincidental casualty

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as for this, it proceeds from my neighbour, my kinsman, my fellow: through his ignorance indeed, because he knows not what is truly natural unto him: but I know it, and therefore carry myself towards him according to the natural law of fellowship; that is kindly, and justly.
sentences: and as for this it proceeds from my neighbour my kinsman my fellow through his ignorance indeed because he knows not what is truly natural unto him but know it and therefore carry myself towards him according to the natural law of fellowship that is kindly and justly

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As for those things that of themselves are altogether indifferent, as in my best judgment I conceive everything to deserve more or less, so I carry myself towards it.
sentences: as for those things that of themselves are altogether indifferent as in my best judgment conceive everything to deserve more or less so carry myself towards it

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If thou shalt intend that which is present, following the rule of right and reason carefully, solidly, meekly, and shalt not intermix any other businesses, but shall study this only to preserve thy spirit unpolluted, and pure, and shall cleave unto him without either hope or fear of anything, in all things that thou shalt either do or speak, contenting thyself with heroical truth, thou shalt live happily; and from this, there is no man that can hinder thee.
sentences: if thou shalt intend that which is present following the rule of right and reason carefully solidly meekly and shalt not intermix any other businesses but shall study this only to preserve thy spirit unpolluted and pure and shall cleave unto him without either hope or fear of anything in all things that thou shalt either do or speak contenting thyself with heroical truth thou shalt live happily and from this there is no man that can hinder thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As physicians and chirurgeons have always their instruments ready at hand for all sudden cures; so have thou always thy dogmata in a readiness for the knowledge of things, both divine and human: and whatsoever
sentences: as physicians and chirurgeons have always their instruments ready at hand for all sudden cures so have thou always thy dogmata in readiness for the knowledge of things both divine and human and whatsoever

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: thou dost, even in the smallest things that thou dost, thou must ever remember that mutual relation, and connection that is between these two things divine, and things human.
sentences: thou dost even in the smallest things that thou dost thou must ever remember that mutual relation and connection that is between these two things divine and things human

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For without relation unto God, thou shalt never speed in any worldly actions; nor on the other side in any divine, without some respect had to things human.
sentences: for without relation unto god thou shalt never speed in any worldly actions nor on the other side in any divine without some respect had to things human

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Be not deceived; for thou shalt never live to read thy moral commentaries, nor the acts of the famous Romans and Grecians; nor those excerpta from several books; all which thou hadst provided and laid up for thyself against thine old age.
sentences: be not deceived for thou shalt never live to read thy moral commentaries nor the acts of the famous romans and grecians nor those excerpta from several books all which thou hadst provided and laid up for thyself against thine old age

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Hasten therefore to an end, and giving over all vain hopes, help thyself in time if thou carest for thyself, as thou oughtest to do.
sentences: hasten therefore to an end and giving over all vain hopes help thyself in time if thou carest for thyself as thou oughtest to do

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: To steal, to sow, to buy, to be at rest, to see what is to be done (which is not seen by the eyes, but by another kind of sight:) what these words mean, and how many ways to be understood, they do not understand.
sentences: to steal to sow to buy to be at rest to see what is to be done which is not seen by the eyes but by another kind of sight what these words mean and how many ways to be understood they do not understand

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The body, the soul, the understanding.
sentences: the body the soul the understanding

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As the senses naturally belong to the body, and the desires and affections to the soul, so do the dogmata to the understanding.
sentences: as the senses naturally belong to the body and the desires and affections to the soul so do the dogmata to the understanding

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: To be capable of fancies and imaginations, is common to man and beast.
sentences: to be capable of fancies and imaginations is common to man and beast

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: To be violently drawn and moved by the lusts and desires of the soul, is proper to wild beasts and monsters, such as Phalaris and Nero were.
sentences: to be violently drawn and moved by the lusts and desires of the soul is proper to wild beasts and monsters such as phalaris and nero were

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: To follow reason for ordinary duties and actions is common to them also, who believe not that there be any gods, and for their advantage would make no conscience to betray their own country; and who when once the doors be shut upon them, dare do anything.
sentences: to follow reason for ordinary duties and actions is common to them also who believe not that there be any gods and for their advantage would make no conscience to betray their own country and who when once the doors be shut upon them dare do anything

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If therefore all things else be common to these likewise, it follows, that for a man to like and embrace all things that happen and are destinated unto him, and not to trouble and molest that spirit which is seated in the temple of his own breast, with a multitude of vain fancies and imaginations, but to keep him propitious and to obey him as a god, never either speaking anything contrary to truth, or doing anything contrary to justice, is the only true property of a good man.
sentences: if therefore all things else be common to these likewise it follows that for man to like and embrace all things that happen and are destinated unto him and not to trouble and molest that spirit which is seated in the temple of his own breast with multitude of vain fancies and imaginations but to keep him propitious and to obey him as god never either speaking anything contrary to truth or doing anything contrary to justice is the only true property of good man

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And such a one, though no man should believe that he liveth as he doth, either sincerely and conscionably, or cheerful and contentedly; yet is he neither with any man at all angry for it, nor diverted by it from the way that leadeth to the end of his life, through which a man must pass pure, ever ready to depart, and willing of himself without any compulsion to fit and accommodate himself to his proper lot and portion.
sentences: and such one though no man should believe that he liveth as he doth either sincerely and conscionably or cheerful and contentedly yet is he neither with any man at all angry for it nor diverted by it from the way that leadeth to the end of his life through which man must pass pure ever ready to depart and willing of himself without any compulsion to fit and accommodate himself to his proper lot and portion

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: That inward mistress part of man if it be in its own true natural temper, is towards all worldly chances and events ever so disposed and affected, that it will easily turn and apply itself to that which may be, and is within its own power to compass, when that cannot be which at first it intended.
sentences: that inward mistress part of man if it be in its own true natural temper is towards all worldly chances and events ever so disposed and affected that it will easily turn and apply itself to that which may be and is within its own power to compass when that cannot be which at first it intended

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For it never doth absolutely addict and apply itself to any one object, but whatsoever it is that it doth now intend and prosecute, it doth prosecute it with exception and reservation;
sentences: for it never doth absolutely addict and apply itself to any one object but whatsoever it is that it doth now intend and prosecute it doth prosecute it with exception and reservation

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: so that whatsoever it is that falls out contrary to its first intentions, even that afterwards it makes its proper object.
sentences: so that whatsoever it is that falls out contrary to its first intentions even that afterwards it makes its proper object

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Even as the fire when it prevails upon those things that are in his way; by which things indeed a little fire would have been quenched, but a great fire doth soon turn to its own nature, and so consume whatsoever comes in his way:
sentences: even as the fire when it prevails upon those things that are in his way by which things indeed little fire would have been quenched but great fire doth soon turn to its own nature and so consume whatsoever comes in his way

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: yea by those very things it is made greater and greater.
sentences: yea by those very things it is made greater and greater

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Let nothing be done rashly, and at random, but all things according to the most exact and perfect rules of art.
sentences: let nothing be done rashly and at random but all things according to the most exact and perfect rules of art

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: They seek for themselves private retiring places, as country villages, the sea shore, mountains; yea thou thyself art wont to long much after such places.
sentences: they seek for themselves private retiring places as country villages the sea shore mountains yea thou thyself art wont to long much after such places

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But all this thou must know proceeds from simplicity in the highest degree.
sentences: but all this thou must know proceeds from simplicity in the highest degree

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: At what time soever thou wilt, it is in thy power to retire into thyself, and to be at rest, and free from all businesses.
sentences: at what time soever thou wilt it is in thy power to retire into thyself and to be at rest and free from all businesses

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: A man cannot any whither retire better than to his own soul; he especially who is beforehand provided of such things within, which whensoever he doth withdraw himself to look in, may presently afford unto him perfect ease and tranquillity.
sentences: man cannot any whither retire better than to his own soul he especially who is beforehand provided of such things within which whensoever he doth withdraw himself to look in may presently afford unto him perfect ease and tranquillity

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: By tranquillity I understand a decent orderly disposition and carriage, free from all confusion and tumultuousness.
sentences: by tranquillity understand decent orderly disposition and carriage free from all confusion and tumultuousness

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Afford then thyself this retiring continually, and thereby refresh and renew thyself.
sentences: afford then thyself this retiring continually and thereby refresh and renew thyself

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Let these precepts be brief and fundamental, which as soon as thou dost call them to mind, may suffice thee to purge thy soul throughly, and to send thee away well pleased with those things whatsoever they be, which now again after this short withdrawing of thy soul into herself thou dost return unto.
sentences: let these precepts be brief and fundamental which as soon as thou dost call them to mind may suffice thee to purge thy soul throughly and to send thee away well pleased with those things whatsoever they be which now again after this short withdrawing of thy soul into herself thou dost return unto

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For what is it that thou art offended at?
sentences: for what is it that thou art offended at

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Can it be at the wickedness of men, when thou dost call to mind this conclusion, that all reasonable creatures are made one for another?
sentences: can it be at the wickedness of men when thou dost call to mind this conclusion that all reasonable creatures are made one for another

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: and that it is part of justice to bear with them?
sentences: and that it is part of justice to bear with them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: and that it is against their wills that they offend?
sentences: and that it is against their wills that they offend

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: and how many already, who once likewise prosecuted their enmities, suspected, hated, and fiercely contended, are now long ago stretched out, and reduced unto ashes?
sentences: and how many already who once likewise prosecuted their enmities suspected hated and fiercely contended are now long ago stretched out and reduced unto ashes

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: It is time for thee to make an end.
sentences: it is time for thee to make an end

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As for those things which among the common chances of the world happen unto thee as thy particular lot and portion, canst thou be displeased with any of them, when thou dost call that our ordinary dilemma to mind, either a providence, or Democritus his atoms; and with it, whatsoever we brought to prove that the whole world is as it were one city?
sentences: as for those things which among the common chances of the world happen unto thee as thy particular lot and portion canst thou be displeased with any of them when thou dost call that our ordinary dilemma to mind either providence or democritus his atoms and with it whatsoever we brought to prove that the whole world is as it were one city

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as for thy body, what canst thou fear, if thou dost consider that thy mind and understanding, when once it hath recollected itself, and knows its own power, hath in this life and breath (whether it run smoothly and gently, or whether harshly and rudely),
sentences: and as for thy body what canst thou fear if thou dost consider that thy mind and understanding when once it hath recollected itself and knows its own power hath in this life and breath whether it run smoothly and gently or whether harshly and rudely

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: no interest at all, but is altogether indifferent: and whatsoever else
sentences: no interest at all but is altogether indifferent and whatsoever else

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: hast heard and assented unto concerning either pain or pleasure?
sentences: hast heard and assented unto concerning either pain or pleasure

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But the care of thine honour and reputation will perchance distract thee?
sentences: but the care of thine honour and reputation will perchance distract thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: How can that be, if thou dost look back, and consider both how quickly all things that are, are forgotten, and what an immense chaos of eternity was before, and will follow after all things: and the vanity of praise, and the inconstancy and variableness of human judgments and opinions, and the narrowness of the place, wherein it is limited and circumscribed?
sentences: how can that be if thou dost look back and consider both how quickly all things that are are forgotten and what an immense chaos of eternity was before and will follow after all things and the vanity of praise and the inconstancy and variableness of human judgments and opinions and the narrowness of the place wherein it is limited and circumscribed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For the whole earth is but as one point; and of it, this inhabited part of it, is but a very little part; and of this part, how many in number, and what manner of men are they, that will commend thee?
sentences: for the whole earth is but as one point and of it this inhabited part of it is but very little part and of this part how many in number and what manner of men are they that will commend thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: What remains then, but that thou often put in practice this kind of retiring of thyself, to this little part of thyself; and above all things, keep thyself from distraction, and intend not anything vehemently, but be free and consider all things, as a man whose proper object is Virtue, as a man whose true nature is to be kind and sociable, as a citizen, as a mortal creature.
sentences: what remains then but that thou often put in practice this kind of retiring of thyself to this little part of thyself and above all things keep thyself from distraction and intend not anything vehemently but be free and consider all things as man whose proper object is virtue as man whose true nature is to be kind and sociable as citizen as mortal creature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Among other things, which to consider, and look into thou must use to withdraw thyself, let those two be among the most obvious and at hand.
sentences: among other things which to consider and look into thou must use to withdraw thyself let those two be among the most obvious and at hand

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: One, that the things or objects themselves reach not unto the soul, but stand without still and quiet, and that it is from the opinion only which is within, that all the tumult and all the trouble doth proceed.
sentences: one that the things or objects themselves reach not unto the soul but stand without still and quiet and that it is from the opinion only which is within that all the tumult and all the trouble doth proceed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: The next, that all these things, which now thou seest, shall within a very little while be changed, and be no more: and ever call to mind, how many changes and alterations in the world thou thyself hast already been an eyewitness of in thy time.
sentences: the next that all these things which now thou seest shall within very little while be changed and be no more and ever call to mind how many changes and alterations in the world thou thyself hast already been an eyewitness of in thy time

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: This world is mere change, and this life, opinion.
sentences: this world is mere change and this life opinion

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If to understand and to be reasonable be common unto all men, then is that reason, for which we are termed reasonable, common unto all.
sentences: if to understand and to be reasonable be common unto all men then is that reason for which we are termed reasonable common unto all

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If reason is general, then is that reason also, which prescribeth what is to be done and what not, common unto all.
sentences: if reason is general then is that reason also which prescribeth what is to be done and what not common unto all

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If law, then are we fellow citizens.
sentences: if law then are we fellow citizens

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If so, then are we partners in some one commonweal.
sentences: if so then are we partners in some one commonweal

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If so, then the world is as it were a city.
sentences: if so then the world is as it were city

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For which other commonweal is it, that all men can be said to be members of?
sentences: for which other commonweal is it that all men can be said to be members of

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: From this common city it is, that understanding, reason, and law is derived unto us, for from whence else?
sentences: from this common city it is that understanding reason and law is derived unto us for from whence else

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For as that which in me is earthly
sentences: for as that which in me is earthly

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: have from some common earth and that which is moist from some other element is imparted as my breath and life hath its proper fountain and that likewise which is dry and fiery in me for there is nothing which doth not proceed from something

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: ; as also there is nothing that can be reduced unto mere nothing:)
sentences: as also there is nothing that can be reduced unto mere nothing

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: so also is there some common beginning from whence
sentences: so also is there some common beginning from whence

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: my understanding hath proceeded.
sentences: my understanding hath proceeded

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As generation is, so also death, a secret of nature's wisdom: a mixture of elements, resolved into the same elements again, a thing surely which no man ought to be ashamed of: in a series of other fatal events and consequences, which a rational creature is subject unto, not improper or incongruous, nor contrary to the natural and proper constitution of man himself.

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Others again there be, who when they have done any such thing, do not so much as know what they have done; but are like unto the vine, which beareth her grapes, and when once she hath borne her own proper fruit, is contented and seeks for no further recompense.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As a horse after a race, and a hunting dog when he hath hunted, and a bee when she hath made her honey, look not for applause and commendation; so neither doth that man that rightly doth understand his own nature when he hath done a good turn: but from one doth proceed to do another, even as the vine after she hath once borne fruit in her own proper season, is ready for another time.

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Remember his resolute constancy in things that were done by him according to reason, his equability in all things, his sanctity; the cheerfulness of his countenance, his sweetness, and how free he was from all vainglory; how careful to come to the true and exact knowledge of matters in hand, and how he would by no means give over till he did fully, and plainly understand the whole state of the business; and how patiently, and without any contestation he would bear with them, that did unjustly condemn him: how he would never be over hasty in anything, nor give ear to slanders and false accusations, but examine and observe with best diligence the several actions and dispositions of men.
sentences: remember his resolute constancy in things that were done by him according to reason his equability in all things his sanctity the cheerfulness of his countenance his sweetness and how free he was from all vainglory how careful to come to the true and exact knowledge of matters in hand and how he would by no means give over till he did fully and plainly understand the whole state of the business and how patiently and without any contestation he would bear with them that did unjustly condemn him how he would never be over hasty in anything nor give ear to slanders and false accusations but examine and observe with best diligence the several actions and dispositions of men

sentence_str: And as by any solid body, that it meets with in the way that is not penetrable by air, it is divided and abrupted, and yet neither slides off, or falls down, but stayeth there nevertheless: such must the diffusion in the mind be; not an effusion, but an extension.

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For the nature of the universe, having made all reasonable creatures one for another, to the end that they should do one another good; more or less according to the several persons and occasions but in nowise hurt one another: it is manifest that he that doth transgress against this her will, is guilty of impiety towards the most ancient and venerable of all the deities.
sentences: for the nature of the universe having made all reasonable creatures one for another to the end that they should do one another good more or less according to the several persons and occasions but in nowise hurt one another it is manifest that he that doth transgress against this her will is guilty of impiety towards the most ancient and venerable of all the deities

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For the nature of the universe, is the nature the common parent of all, and therefore piously to be observed of all things that are, and that which now is, to whatsoever first was, and gave it its being, hath relation of blood and kindred.
sentences: for the nature of the universe is the nature the common parent of all and therefore piously to be observed of all things that are and that which now is to whatsoever first was and gave it its being hath relation of blood and kindred

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: She is also called truth and is the first cause of all truths.
sentences: she is also called truth and is the first cause of all truths

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: He therefore that willingly and wittingly doth lie, is impious in that he doth receive, and so commit injustice: but he that against his will, in that he disagreeth from the nature of the universe, and in that striving with the nature of the world he doth in his particular, violate the general order of the world.
sentences: he therefore that willingly and wittingly doth lie is impious in that he doth receive and so commit injustice but he that against his will in that he disagreeth from the nature of the universe and in that striving with the nature of the world he doth in his particular violate the general order of the world

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For he doth no better than strive and war against it, who contrary to his own nature applieth himself to that which is contrary to truth.
sentences: for he doth no better than strive and war against it who contrary to his own nature applieth himself to that which is contrary to truth

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For nature had before furnished him with instincts and opportunities sufficient for the attainment of it; which he having hitherto neglected, is not now able to discern that which is false from that which is true.
sentences: for nature had before furnished him with instincts and opportunities sufficient for the attainment of it which he having hitherto neglected is not now able to discern that which is false from that which is true

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: he also that pursues after pleasures as that which is truly good and flies from pains as that which is truly evil is impious

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For such a one must of necessity oftentimes accuse that common nature, as distributing many things both unto the evil, and unto the good, not according to the deserts of either: as unto the bad oftentimes pleasures, and the causes of pleasures; so unto the good, pains, and the occasions of pains.
sentences: for such one must of necessity oftentimes accuse that common nature as distributing many things both unto the evil and unto the good not according to the deserts of either as unto the bad oftentimes pleasures and the causes of pleasures so unto the good pains and the occasions of pains

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: they that will live according to nature must in those things as being of the same mind and disposition that she is be as equally indifferent

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whosoever therefore in either matter of pleasure and pain; death and life; honour and dishonour, (which things nature in the administration of the world, indifferently doth make use of), is not as indifferent, it is apparent that he is impious.
sentences: whosoever therefore in either matter of pleasure and pain death and life honour and dishonour which things nature in the administration of the world indifferently doth make use of is not as indifferent it is apparent that he is impious

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: When I say that common nature doth indifferently make use of them, my meaning is, that they happen indifferently in the ordinary course of things, which by a necessary consequence, whether as principal or accessory, come to pass in the world, according to that first and ancient deliberation of Providence, by which she from some certain beginning, did resolve upon the creation of such a world, conceiving then in her womb as it were some certain rational generative seeds and faculties of things future, whether subjects, changes, successions; both such and such, and just so many.
sentences: when say that common nature doth indifferently make use of them my meaning is that they happen indifferently in the ordinary course of things which by necessary consequence whether as principal or accessory come to pass in the world according to that first and ancient deliberation of providence by which she from some certain beginning did resolve upon the creation of such world conceiving then in her womb as it were some certain rational generative seeds and faculties of things future whether subjects changes successions both such and such and just so many

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: It is therefore the part of a wise man, in matter of death, not in any wise to carry himself either violently, or proudly but patiently to wait for it, as one of nature's operations: that with the same mind as now thou dost expect when that which yet is but an embryo in thy wife's belly shall come forth, thou
sentences: it is therefore the part of wise man in matter of death not in any wise to carry himself either violently or proudly but patiently to wait for it as one of nature operations that with the same mind as now thou dost expect when that which yet is but an embryo in thy wife belly shall come forth thou

author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: mayst expect also when thy soul shall fall off from that outward coat or skin wherein as child in the belly it lieth involved and shut up

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But thou desirest a more popular, and though not so direct and philosophical, yet a very powerful and penetrative recipe against the fear of death, nothing can make they more willing to part with thy life, than if thou shalt consider, both what the subjects themselves are that thou shalt part with, and what manner of disposition
sentences: but thou desirest more popular and though not so direct and philosophical yet very powerful and penetrative recipe against the fear of death nothing can make they more willing to part with thy life than if thou shalt consider both what the subjects themselves are that thou shalt part with and what manner of disposition

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So that without some obstacle, and some kind of violence, they cannot well be kept asunder.
sentences: so that without some obstacle and some kind of violence they cannot well be kept asunder

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: whatsoever is fiery doth not only by reason of the elementary fire tend upwards but here also is so ready to join and to burn together that whatsoever doth want sufficient moisture to make resistance is easily set on fire

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever therefore is partaker of that reasonable common nature, naturally doth as much and more long after his own kind.
sentences: whatsoever therefore is partaker of that reasonable common nature naturally doth as much and more long after his own kind

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For by how much in its own nature it excels all other things, by so much more is it desirous to be joined and united unto that, which is of its own nature.
sentences: for by how much in its own nature it excels all other things by so much more is it desirous to be joined and united unto that which is of its own nature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As for unreasonable creatures then, they had not long been, but presently begun among them swarms, and flocks, and broods of young ones, and a kind of mutual love and affection.
sentences: as for unreasonable creatures then they had not long been but presently begun among them swarms and flocks and broods of young ones and kind of mutual love and affection

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For though but unreasonable, yet a kind of soul these had, and therefore was that natural desire of union more strong and intense in them, as in creatures of a more excellent nature, than either in plants, or stones, or trees.
sentences: for though but unreasonable yet kind of soul these had and therefore was that natural desire of union more strong and intense in them as in creatures of more excellent nature than either in plants or stones or trees

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But among reasonable creatures, begun commonwealths, friendships, families, public meetings, and even in their wars, conventions, and truces.
sentences: but among reasonable creatures begun commonwealths friendships families public meetings and even in their wars conventions and truces

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Now among them that were yet of a more excellent nature, as the stars and planets, though by their nature far distant one from another, yet even among them began some mutual correspondency and unity.
sentences: now among them that were yet of more excellent nature as the stars and planets though by their nature far distant one from another yet even among them began some mutual correspondency and unity

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So proper is it to excellency in a high degree to affect unity, as that even in things so far distant, it could operate unto a mutual sympathy.
sentences: so proper is it to excellency in high degree to affect unity as that even in things so far distant it could operate unto mutual sympathy

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: , what is now come to pass.
sentences: what is now come to pass

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Those creatures that are reasonable, are now the only creatures that have forgotten their natural affection and inclination of one towards another.
sentences: those creatures that are reasonable are now the only creatures that have forgotten their natural affection and inclination of one towards another

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But though they fly from nature, yet are they stopt in their course, and apprehended.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations

sentences: nay have cast out all my trouble it should rather be for that which troubled thee whatsoever it was was not without anywhere that thou shouldest come out of it but within in thine own opinions from whence it must be cast out before thou canst truly and constantly be at ease

sentence_str: Why not rather, that thou mayst not at either their absence or presence, be grieved and discontented: than either that thou mayst obtain them, or that thou mayst avoid them?
sentences: why not rather that thou mayst not at either their absence or presence be grieved and discontented than either that thou mayst obtain them or that thou mayst avoid them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For certainly it must needs be, that if the Gods can help us in anything, they may in this kind also.
sentences: for certainly it must needs be that if the gods can help us in anything they may in this kind also

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But thou wilt say perchance, 'In those things the Gods have given me my liberty: and it is in mine own power to do what I will.'
sentences: but thou wilt say perchance in those things the gods have given me my liberty and it is in mine own power to do what will

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But if thou mayst use this liberty, rather to set thy mind at true liberty, than wilfully with baseness and servility of mind to affect those things, which either to compass or to avoid is not in thy power, wert not thou better?
sentences: but if thou mayst use this liberty rather to set thy mind at true liberty than wilfully with baseness and servility of mind to affect those things which either to compass or to avoid is not in thy power wert not thou better

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as for the Gods, who hath told thee, that they may not help us up even in those things that they have put in our own power?
sentences: and as for the gods who hath told thee that they may not help us up even in those things that they have put in our own power

author: Marcus Aurelius

sentences: whether it be so or no thou shalt soon perceive if thou wilt but try thyself and pray

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: In my sickness' (saith Epicurus of himself:) 'my discourses were not concerning the nature of my disease, neither was that, to them that came to visit me, the subject of my talk; but in the consideration and contemplation of that, which was of especial weight and moment, was all my time bestowed and spent, and among others in this very thing, how my mind, by a natural and unavoidable sympathy partaking in some sort with the present indisposition of my body, might nevertheless keep herself free from trouble, and in present possession of her own proper happiness.
sentences: in my sickness saith epicurus of himself my discourses were not concerning the nature of my disease neither was that to them that came to visit me the subject of my talk but in the consideration and contemplation of that which was of especial weight and moment was all my time bestowed and spent and among others in this very thing how my mind by natural and unavoidable sympathy partaking in some sort with the present indisposition of my body might nevertheless keep herself free from trouble and in present possession of her own proper happiness

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Neither did I leave the ordering of my body to the physicians altogether to do with me
sentences: neither did leave the ordering of my body to the physicians altogether to do with me

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: what they would, as though I expected any great matter from them, or as though I thought it a matter of such great consequence, by their means to recover my health: for my present estate, methought, liked me very well, and gave me good content.
sentences: what they would as though expected any great matter from them or as though thought it matter of such great consequence by their means to recover my health for my present estate methought liked me very well and gave me good content

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whether therefore in sickness (if thou chance to sicken) or in what other kind of extremity soever, endeavour thou also to be in thy mind so affected, as he doth report of himself: not to depart from thy philosophy for anything that can befall thee, nor to give ear to the discourses of silly people, and mere naturalists.
sentences: whether therefore in sickness if thou chance to sicken or in what other kind of extremity soever endeavour thou also to be in thy mind so affected as he doth report of himself not to depart from thy philosophy for anything that can befall thee nor to give ear to the discourses of silly people and mere naturalists

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: It is common to all trades and professions to mind and intend that only, which now they are about, and the instrument whereby they work.
sentences: it is common to all trades and professions to mind and intend that only which now they are about and the instrument whereby they work

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: When at any time thou art offended with any one's impudency, put presently this question to thyself: 'What?

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So of the subtile and crafty, so of the perfidious, so of every one that offendeth, must thou ever be ready to reason with thyself.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For whilst in general thou dost thus reason with thyself, that the kind of them must needs be in the world, thou wilt
sentences: for whilst in general thou dost thus reason with thyself that the kind of them must needs be in the world thou wilt

sentences: be the better able to use meekness towards every particular

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: This also thou shalt find of very good use, upon every such occasion, presently to consider with thyself, what proper virtue nature hath furnished man with, against such a vice, or to encounter with a disposition vicious in this kind.
sentences: this also thou shalt find of very good use upon every such occasion presently to consider with thyself what proper virtue nature hath furnished man with against such vice or to encounter with disposition vicious in this kind

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As for example, against the unthankful, it hath given goodness and meekness, as an antidote, and so against another vicious in another kind some other peculiar faculty.
sentences: as for example against the unthankful it hath given goodness and meekness as an antidote and so against another vicious in another kind some other peculiar faculty

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And generally, is it not in thy power to instruct him better, that is in an error?
sentences: and generally is it not in thy power to instruct him better that is in an error

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For whosoever sinneth, doth in that decline from his purposed end, and is certainly deceived, And again, what art thou the worse for his sin?
sentences: for whosoever sinneth doth in that decline from his purposed end and is certainly deceived and again what art thou the worse for his sin

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For thou shalt not find that any one of these, against whom thou art incensed, hath in very deed done anything whereby thy mind (the only true subject of thy hurt and evil) can be made worse than it was.
sentences: for thou shalt not find that any one of these against whom thou art incensed hath in very deed done anything whereby thy mind the only true subject of thy hurt and evil can be made worse than it was

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And what a matter of either grief or wonder is this, if he that is unlearned, do the deeds of one that is unlearned?
sentences: and what matter of either grief or wonder is this if he that is unlearned do the deeds of one that is unlearned

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Should not thou rather blame thyself, who, when upon very good grounds of reason, thou mightst have thought it very probable, that such a thing would by such a one be committed, didst not only not foresee it, but moreover dost wonder at it, that such a thing should be.
sentences: should not thou rather blame thyself who when upon very good grounds of reason thou mightst have thought it very probable that such thing would by such one be committed didst not only not foresee it but moreover dost wonder at it that such thing should be

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But then especially, when thou

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For without all question, thou thyself art much in fault, if either of one that were of such a disposition, thou didst expect that he should be true unto thee: or when unto any thou didst a good turn, thou didst not there bound thy thoughts, as one that had obtained his end; nor didst not think that from the action itself thou hadst received a full reward of the good that thou hadst done.
sentences: for without all question thou thyself art much in fault if either of one that were of such disposition thou didst expect that he should be true unto thee or when unto any thou didst good turn thou didst not there bound thy thoughts as one that had obtained his end nor didst not think that from the action itself thou hadst received full reward of the good that thou hadst done

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For what wouldst thou have more?

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For as these being by nature appointed for such an use, can challenge no more, than that they may work according to their natural constitution: so man being born to do good unto others whensoever he doth a real good unto any by helping them out of error; or though but in middle things, as in matter of wealth, life, preferment, and the like, doth help to further their desires he doth that for which he was made, and therefore can require no more.
sentences: for as these being by nature appointed for such an use can challenge no more than that they may work according to their natural constitution so man being born to do good unto others whensoever he doth real good unto any by helping them out of error or though but in middle things as in matter of wealth life preferment and the like doth help to further their desires he doth that for which he was made and therefore can require no more

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: my soul, the time I trust will be, when thou shalt be good, simple, single, more open and visible, than that body by which it is enclosed.
sentences: my soul the time trust will be when thou shalt be good simple single more open and visible than that body by which it is enclosed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Thou wilt one day be sensible of their happiness, whose end is love, and their affections dead to all worldly things.
sentences: thou wilt one day be sensible of their happiness whose end is love and their affections dead to all worldly things

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Thou shalt one day be full, and in want of no external thing: not seeking pleasure from anything, either living or insensible, that this world can afford; neither wanting time for the continuation of thy pleasure, nor place and opportunity, nor the favour either of the weather or of men.
sentences: thou shalt one day be full and in want of no external thing not seeking pleasure from anything either living or insensible that this world can afford neither wanting time for the continuation of thy pleasure nor place and opportunity nor the favour either of the weather or of men

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: When thou shalt have content in thy present estate, and all things present shall add to thy content
sentences: when thou shalt have content in thy present estate and all things present shall add to thy content

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: : when thou shalt persuade thyself, that thou hast all things; all for thy good, and all by the providence of the Gods: and of things future also shalt be as confident, that all will do well, as tending to the maintenance and preservation in some sort, of his perfect welfare and happiness, who is perfection of life, of goodness, and beauty; who begets all things, and containeth all things in himself, and in himself doth recollect all things from all places that are dissolved, that of them he may beget others again like unto them.
sentences: when thou shalt persuade thyself that thou hast all things all for thy good and all by the providence of the gods and of things future also shalt be as confident that all will do well as tending to the maintenance and preservation in some sort of his perfect welfare and happiness who is perfection of life of goodness and beauty who begets all things and containeth all things in himself and in himself doth recollect all things from all places that are dissolved that of them he may beget others again like unto them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Such one day shall be thy disposition, that thou shalt be able, both in regard of the Gods, and in regard of men, so to fit and order thy conversation, as neither to complain of them at any time, for anything that they do; nor to do anything thyself, for which thou mayest justly be condemned.
sentences: such one day shall be thy disposition that thou shalt be able both in regard of the gods and in regard of men so to fit and order thy conversation as neither to complain of them at any time for anything that they do nor to do anything thyself for which thou mayest justly be condemned

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As one who is altogether governed by nature, let it be thy care to observe what it is that thy nature in general doth require.
sentences: as one who is altogether governed by nature let it be thy care to observe what it is that thy nature in general doth require

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever doth happen unto thee, thou art naturally by thy natural constitution either able, or not able to bear.

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: If thou beest not able, be not offended.

author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For it will soon make an end of thee, and itself, (whatsoever it be) at the same time end with thee.
sentences: for it will soon make an end of thee and itself whatsoever it be at the same time end with thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But remember, that whatsoever by the strength of opinion, grounded upon a certain apprehension of both true profit and duty, thou canst conceive tolerable; that thou art able to bear that by thy natural constitution.
sentences: but remember that whatsoever by the strength of opinion grounded upon certain apprehension of both true profit and duty thou canst conceive tolerable that thou art able to bear that by thy natural constitution

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

author: Marcus Aurelius

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Whatsoever it be that happens unto thee, it is that which from all time was appointed unto thee.
sentences: whatsoever it be that happens unto thee it is that which from all time was appointed unto thee

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For by the same coherence of causes, by which thy substance from all eternity was appointed to be, was also whatsoever should happen unto it, destinated and appointed.
sentences: for by the same coherence of causes by which thy substance from all eternity was appointed to be was also whatsoever should happen unto it destinated and appointed

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Either with Epicurus, we must fondly imagine the atoms to be the cause of all things, or we must needs grant a nature.
sentences: either with epicurus we must fondly imagine the atoms to be the cause of all things or we must needs grant nature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Let this then be thy first ground, that thou art part of that universe, which is governed by nature.
sentences: let this then be thy first ground that thou art part of that universe which is governed by nature

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Then secondly, that to those parts that are of the same kind and nature as thou art, thou hast relation of kindred.
sentences: then secondly that to those parts that are of the same kind and nature as thou art thou hast relation of kindred

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For of these, if I shall always be mindful, first as I am a part, I shall never be displeased with anything, that falls to my particular share of the common chances of the world.
sentences: for of these if shall always be mindful first as am part shall never be displeased with anything that falls to my particular share of the common chances of the world

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For nothing that is behoveful unto the whole, can be truly hurtful to that which is part of it.
sentences: for nothing that is behoveful unto the whole can be truly hurtful to that which is part of it

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For this being the common privilege of all natures, that they contain nothing in themselves that is hurtful unto them; it cannot be that the nature of the universe (whose privilege beyond other particular natures, is, that she cannot against her will by any higher external cause be constrained,) should beget anything and cherish it in her bosom that should tend to her own hurt and prejudice.
sentences: for this being the common privilege of all natures that they contain nothing in themselves that is hurtful unto them it cannot be that the nature of the universe whose privilege beyond other particular natures is that she cannot against her will by any higher external cause be constrained should beget anything and cherish it in her bosom that should tend to her own hurt and prejudice

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: As then I bear in mind that I am a part of such an universe, I shall not be displeased with anything that happens.
sentences: as then bear in mind that am part of such an universe shall not be displeased with anything that happens

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And as I have relation of kindred to those parts that are of the same kind and nature that I am, so I shall be careful to do nothing that is prejudicial to the community, but in all my deliberations shall they that are of my kind ever be; and the common good,
sentences: and as have relation of kindred to those parts that are of the same kind and nature that am so shall be careful to do nothing that is prejudicial to the community but in all my deliberations shall they that are of my kind ever be and the common good

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: that, which all my intentions and resolutions shall drive unto, as that which is contrary unto it, I shall by all means endeavour to prevent and avoid.
sentences: that which all my intentions and resolutions shall drive unto as that which is contrary unto it shall by all means endeavour to prevent and avoid

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: These things once so fixed and concluded, as thou wouldst think him a happy citizen, whose constant study and practice were for the good and benefit of his fellow citizens, and the carriage of the city such towards him, that he were well pleased with it; so must it needs be with thee, that thou shalt live a happy life.
sentences: these things once so fixed and concluded as thou wouldst think him happy citizen whose constant study and practice were for the good and benefit of his fellow citizens and the carriage of the city such towards him that he were well pleased with it so must it needs be with thee that thou shalt live happy life

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: All parts of the world, (all things I mean that are contained within the whole world), must of necessity at some time or other come to corruption.
sentences: all parts of the world all things mean that are contained within the whole world must of necessity at some time or other come to corruption

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Alteration I should say, to speak truly and properly; but that I may be the better understood, I am content at this time to use that more common word.
sentences: alteration should say to speak truly and properly but that may be the better understood am content at this time to use that more common word

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Now say I, if so be that this be both hurtful unto them, and yet unavoidable, would not, thinkest thou, the whole itself be in a sweet case, all the parts of it being subject to alteration, yea and by their making itself fitted for corruption, as consisting of things different and contrary?
sentences: now say if so be that this be both hurtful unto them and yet unavoidable would not thinkest thou the whole itself be in sweet case all the parts of it being subject to alteration yea and by their making itself fitted for corruption as consisting of things different and contrary

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: And did nature then either of herself thus project and purpose the affliction and misery of her parts, and therefore of purpose so made them, not only that haply they might, but of necessity that they should fall into evil; or did not she know what she did, when she made them?
sentences: and did nature then either of herself thus project and purpose the affliction and misery of her parts and therefore of purpose so made them not only that haply they might but of necessity that they should fall into evil or did not she know what she did when she made them

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For either of these two to say, is equally absurd.
sentences: for either of these two to say is equally absurd

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: But to let pass nature in general, and to reason of things particular according to their own particular natures; how absurd and ridiculous is it, first to say that all parts of the whole are, by their proper natural constitution, subject to alteration; and then when any such thing doth happen, as when one doth fall sick and dieth, to take on and wonder as though some strange thing had happened?
sentences: but to let pass nature in general and to reason of things particular according to their own particular natures how absurd and ridiculous is it first to say that all parts of the whole are by their proper natural constitution subject to alteration and then when any such thing doth happen as when one doth fall sick and dieth to take on and wonder as though some strange thing had happened

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Though this besides might move not so grievously to take on when any such thing doth happen, that whatsoever is dissolved, it is dissolved into those things, whereof it was compounded.
sentences: though this besides might move not so grievously to take on when any such thing doth happen that whatsoever is dissolved it is dissolved into those things whereof it was compounded

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: For every dissolution is either a mere dispersion, of the elements into those elements again
sentences: for every dissolution is either mere dispersion of the elements into those elements again

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: whereof everything did consist, or a change, of that which is more solid into earth; and of that which is pure and subtile or spiritual, into air.
sentences: whereof everything did consist or change of that which is more solid into earth and of that which is pure and subtile or spiritual into air

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: So that by this means nothing is lost, but all resumed again into those rational generative seeds of the universe; and this universe, either after a certain period of time to lie consumed by fire, or by continual changes to be renewed, and so for ever to endure.
sentences: so that by this means nothing is lost but all resumed again into those rational generative seeds of the universe and this universe either after certain period of time to lie consumed by fire or by continual changes to be renewed and so for ever to endure

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
sentence_str: Now that solid and spiritual that we speak of, thou must not conceive it to be that very same,
sentences: now that solid and spiritual that we speak of thou must not conceive it to be that very same
